Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

In a few weeks, it will be necessary to supplement the live stock and agricultural machinery and to purchase some workshop tools for the new Blue Quills Indian Residential School. I should be pleased if you would indicate sources of supply for the following:

June 9th,
1931.

The Purchasing Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Canada.

Dear Sir:-

We are advised that it is your intention to purchase in the early future an 800 lb. Electric Cream Separator for your new Indian Industrial School at St. Paul, Alta., and we are wondering if we may ask you to let us figure in this matter. May we also at the outset point out that we are an entirely Canadian company, operating on Canadian capital and employing Canadian workmen making a splendid standard line of cream separators and we certainly would be very pleased indeed if you would give us an opportunity to figure on this particular machine you are purchasing in the near future.

Yours very truly,

H. A. Jordan,
Managing-Director,

[Handwritten note:]
If this style of separator is required, you letter will not be overlooked.
Ottawa, June 16, 1931.

Gentlemen:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, requesting an opportunity to quote on an 800 Lb. electric cream separator for use at the new Indian residential school at St. Paul, Alta.

In reply I have to say that if this type of equipment is required your letter will not be overlooked.

Yours truly,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

The Renfrew Machinery Co. Ltd.,
Renfrew,
Ont.
August 12, 1931.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

With reference to your memorandum of yesterday's date, concerning supplying the Blue Quills Indian Residential School with horses, cattle and machinery, I may say that, during the next few months, a few purchases will have to be made. On April 10th, last, you gave me a memorandum concerning sources of supply for live stock and implements. If there are any others that you wish to have quoted, please let me know.

Concerning the painting of the floors at the new school, I may say it is not the intention to proceed with this work this year.

A. S. Williams,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Ottawa, August 31, 1931.

Mr. Ferrier,

Mr. Buskard wishes to have the following information this afternoon for sure:

How many head of horses and cattle will be required for the Blue Quills school and the approximate price to be paid, also a list of the machinery required.

Acting D. S. G. I. A.
August 31, 1931.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSHARD,

Pursuant to telephone conversation this afternoon, I have to inform you that horses, cattle and agricultural machinery will be purchased for the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, in the electoral district of Athabasca, from time to time, during the next few months, as required. The original requisition from the Reverend Principal indicated that six horses, ten cows and the following agricultural machinery would be required:

- Breaking plough,
- Mower,
- Gang plough,
- Rake,
- Disc,
- Wagon,
- Harrow,
- Bob sleigh.
- Drill.

I may say it is not the intention to purchase any of this equipment until the Reverend Principal writes that particular stock or machinery is then required. The current prices for the locality of St. Paul, Alberta, will be paid when purchase is made. It is possible that a team or two of horses, the ten cows, a harrow, wagon and bob sleigh will be required during the next few months and that the rest of the equipment and stock will be needed in the spring.

A. S. Williams,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Feb.16th 1932

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

With reference to your letter No 118-1-14 of Feb. 4th, relative to the live stock to be supplied to the Blue Quills School, I may say that Mr Charles Gayvreau will be asked to find it and to state price.

As to the veterinary surgeon, I must say that Doctor Bissonnette, who was injured in the car crash where the Hon. Buckley found death, is now unable to work, and then there is still now no other veterinary surgeon at St-Paul.

Truly yours,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.
March 23rd 1932.

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

In reference with your letter No 118-1-14, of Feb. 4th, relative to the machines to be supplied to the Blue Quills School, I may say that, according to your letter, I have asked, 5 weeks ago, for the prices of these, to Mr Charles Gauvreau of St-Paul, but have not got any reply. It is possible that Mr Gauvreau have written to the Department directly.

Considering however that the spring is coming soon and that the agricultural implements will be needed within one month, I have taken the liberty to ask for prices to the principal firms of machinery in St-Paul that have always repairs in hand in stock and I submit below their prices for your information:

| Massey-Harris | Mc Cormick-Deering |
|---------------|-------------------|
| 16" Breaking plow | $92.00 | $93.00 |
| 16" Disc | $92.00 | $88.75 |
| Spring tooth harrow | $90.00 | $90.25 |
| 20 R Drill | $299.00 | $222.50 |
| Bob-sleigh with double-box | $113.50 | $105.00 |

For freight from Edmonton to St-Paul | $27.44 |

The Massey-Harris firm gives a 7% discount on Machinery, and 5% on sleigh, so that the amount totals to $575.65.

The Mc Cormick-Deering firm gives a 10% discount on all, so that the amount totals to $566.99.

I know that Mr Gauvreau has yet some machines from Lacrosse Flow Works, of Racine, Wisc. I would be very obliged to the Department not to furnish these same machines to the school, as it takes 3 weeks before getting repairs from Racine, Wisc.

Truly yours,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.
To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

In reply to your letter No 118-1-14, of Feb. 4th, concerning the livestock to be supplied to the Blue Quills School, I must say that Mr Charles Gauvreau of St-Paul, has submitted no price till now.

Then I can state for your information that the farmers here around the school could supply 10 good cows, fresh, young, healthy for the price of $50.00 per head, and below. Those cows are not Shorthorn, but Ayrshires mixed up with Pure Shorthorn.

As to one bull, I have no reference to submit now.

Truly yours,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.
Ottawa, July 5, 1932.

- 1 spring tooth harrow with truck $9.00
- √ 1 20-run drill $24.99

Sir:-

August 26th 1932.

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have already written to you about the fencing of the playgrounds for the pupils, and I must again draw your attention on this fact that the pupils being come back, it is difficult to watch over them. The playgrounds should be fenced the soonest possible, chiefly when it is time yet to make fence; pretty soon, it will be too cold to have the playgrounds fenced.

The pump is working very badly and I fear it breaks sometime. Mr. Indian Agent Gullion has been advised two months ago and I asked at this time that the pump be taken off and fixed up again. Would it be possible that the man who has settled down this pump come again to see about it?

Our wheat is already cut and pretty soon it will be the turn of the oats to be cut, and afterwards the thrashing will take place. I get you remember that we have no granary and no other place to put our crop. Therefore a granary should be built very soon. I hope you will take steps in this connection.

Yours truly,

Rev. Jos. Angin,
Principal.
Ottawa, September 1st, 1932.

Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost and attach same to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment.

Calgary, Alta.

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 1st instant in connection with the agricultural implements, fencing, and cattle asked for by the Blue Quills Indian Residential School at St. Paul. You have my report on this school dated the 24th ultimo, and you will note that I have stated that the following agricultural implements will be required:

- 1 - 16" Breaking Plow (Not required until Spring)
- 1 - 16" Disk
- 1 - 20-run Drill
- 1 - set spring toothed Harrows
- 1 - Bob sleight with box - Required this fall.

The fencing is for the playgrounds, and when I was there the Principal estimated the cost at $250. These grounds should, of course, be fenced, but there is no reason why this cannot be held over until spring, if necessary. In any event, I am not very much in favour of fencing playgrounds with woven wire as it soon gets out of shape from the boys standing on it, &c. I think plain wire with a rail on top of the fence would be more suitable.

With reference to the milch cows and bull: No doubt this school requires additional cows as they only have seven at the present time, but if say five additional cows were supplied this fall, I think that would be sufficient to meet the requirements of the school at least until spring. The bull of course is not required until spring, and can be purchased at the Edmonton bull sale which is held about the 1st of April. The approximate cost of good milch cows would be between $50 and $60.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Therefore.......
Therefore, all that would be absolutely necessary to supply at the present time would be the Bob-sleigh and box at a cost of about $90 and five cows at an approximate cost of $300. I note that the Department state arrangements could be made with Chas. Gauvreau for supplying cows and farm implements, and they desire to know the cost of same; I am of the opinion that this man is not a dealer in any of the lines mentioned. The Bob-sleigh and box could be bought in the usual manner and delivered through an implement dealer at St. Paul, and Mr. Gullion, the Agent, is quite capable of purchasing the cows, from the farmers in that district. Of course if the Department wish to place the purchasing of these implements, &c., in the hands of Mr. Gauvreau, I will see that this is done.

I might also refer to the granary which was mentioned in my recent report on this school; This is something that is required by the school this fall, if there is any means whatever of financing it.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christiansen,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.
September 17, 1932.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

It is necessary at the present time to purchase five cows and one set of bob sleighs, with box, for the new Blue Quills Indian Residential School at St. Paul, Alta. In April, 1931, you directed that, when cattle and farm machinery were being supplied, the purchase be made from Charles Gauvreau, St. Paul, Alta.

Mr. Inspector Christianson, Calgary, Alta., states he is of opinion that this man is not a dealer in any of the lines mentioned. He recommends that Mr. Gullion, the local Agent, arrange for the purchase of the cows from farmers in that district and that the bob sleigh and box be bought in the usual manner and delivered through an implement dealer in St. Paul. I should be pleased to have your directions regarding the purchase of the above.

It will also be necessary next Spring to purchase a breaking plow, disc, drill and set of spring tooth harrows, also a bull and five cows. I shall be pleased to have your instructions regarding the above purchases.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, in connection with the agricultural implements, fencing and cattle for the Blue Quills Indian Residential School at St. Paul, Alta. It is noted that the only farm equipment required at the present time is one bob sleigh, with box, and I would request that you arrange for the purchase from firms on the list handling these supplies, and have same delivered at the school when considered timely. Please obtain an account, in triplicate, covering the cost, which you should certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Regarding the fencing of the playgrounds, as our funds this year are limited, this work can be held over until next Spring. This matter may be brought to the attention of the Department at that time and full details should be given regarding materials and cost.

With reference to the purchase of milch cows, I have to say that the Department is prepared at the present time to supply the school with five grade milch cows. It is considered that a good type of grade cow would be satisfactory. They should be young and giving milk, or to freshen early in the new year.

You may arrange with Mr. Agent Gullion, if you are assured he is a good judge of cattle, to make the purchase. He should give Mr. Charles Sauvreau, St. Paul, an opportunity to supply the cows, but if Mr. Sauvreau is unable to do so, the Agent may make the purchase locally. It would be advisable that he secure the aid of a Government Livestock Man, if one is in the district, in selecting the cows. All cows should be free from tuberculosis and should be of good milking strain. It is noted you are of opinion that the cost of good milch cows would be between $50 and $75 each. It is hoped that they can be obtained at prices not exceeding this figure. After the Agent has completed the purchase, he should forward for payment accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, in favour of the parties from whom the cows are purchased.

The question of supplying a further number of cows, additional agricultural implements and fencing material will receive consideration this coming Spring.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant in regard to the purchase last year of five cows for the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school. In reply, I wish to submit the following report:

In Mr. Inspector Christianson's letter No. 407-11A of the 26th September, 1932, I received instructions in part as follows: "As to the purchase of additional milch cows, you are hereby authorized to purchase five grade milch cows for the school of a good milch type. You should see the Principal and ascertain from him what would be the most suitable time for the cows to freshen. When the Department wrote to me in this connection I advised them that the cows could be purchased at a price of from $50. to $60., and this amount should not be exceeded. I think we should get exceptionally good cows for even $50. You are aware of the market price at the present time, and I would consider that real good cows can be bought for this amount. In making the purchase you are to give Mr. Gauvreau an opportunity to supply the five cows that are required, but if he is unable to do so, you may purchase them locally wherever you can find suitable ones."

The cows were also to be T.B. tested. On the 13th October, I interviewed Mr. Gauvreau in regard to supplying the five cows required. I advised him as to the kind and type of cows required and also informed him that he should endeavor to see the Reverend Principal of the Blue Quill's school before getting any cows. In my report for the month of October, I mentioned that the cows had not yet been delivered. By letter dated November 23rd, 1932,

Harold W. McGill Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Mr. Inspector Christianson advised me that the matter had already been too long delayed and instructed me to get in touch with the Principal immediately and buy five cows that were suitable to him. I received Mr. Christianson's letter on the 29th November and on the following day, I called at the school and the cows was one of the subjects discussed with Rev. Father Anglin. He informed me that he wished to have at least two cows fresh, the others to freshen before Spring. I was in St. Paul but did not see Mr. Sauvreau on that date. I however, met Mr. Walter Allen from North of St. Paul and he mentioned that Mr. Sauvreau had told him that a number of cows were needed for the school. I advised Mr. Allen that I would look over his cattle as soon as possible. The day following, December 1st, I drove out to Mr. Allen's and looked over his herd. While some of his cattle were fairly smooth, they were not of the larger type and with the exception of one very poor heifer, none of the cows that I looked over had freshened. He had three heifers, I believe rising three years, that I considered the most promising. His cows, I understood, were not freshening until Spring. I advised Mr. Allen that five cows were required for the school and that I wished to get cows that would prove suitable to the Principal. I also told Mr. Allen that I would advise the Principal in regard to his (Mr. Allen's) cattle and that if the Principal considered that they might be suitable, he might drive over and look at them. The Principal, however, did not want any untried milch cows or any that were not going to freshen during the Winter.

As Mr. Sauvreau was apparently making no further efforts to secure the cows, I did not again approach him in connection with the matter and proceeded to carry out Mr. Christianson's instructions. On making enquiries in St. Paul, I was advised by Mr. H.A. Welsh and others, to get in touch with Mr. A.S. Spence, whom it was considered was the most familiar with the stock in the district. On the 3rd December, I got in touch with Mr. Spence and advised him of the kind and type of cows required. The cows were accordingly delivered at the school on the 16th December. I called at the school with Mr. Spence on Saturday the 17th and checked up on the animals with him. The cows supplied were large and of a very good type. One cow had just freshened, one was to freshen at once and another one within ten days, the other two being due to come in a little later. The Reverend Principal informed me that he was very well satisfied with the cows. The cows were purchased with the understanding that they would pass the T.B. test and Mr. Spence is having them tested. Taking the time...
time spent in looking for suitable cows, trucking, etc., into consideration, I was of the opinion that for the type supplied, the cows were reasonably priced.

It was represented to the Department that the cows were purchased at an amount which was $75.00 more than the price quoted by Mr. Allen. The cows furnished were of course worth the difference or I should not have made the purchase. There were cattle in the district that could have been bought at prices even lower than Mr. Allen's but there is the difference between suitable and unsuitable animals to be taken into consideration.

I fail to see any reason why Mr. Sauvreau should feel aggrieved as he was given an opportunity and I think plenty of time, to procure the cows. In this connection, I might mention that when in St. Paul on the 26th January last, Mr. A.U. Lebel asked me to call at his office. I did so and he then brought up the matter of the cows, stating that Mr. Sauvreau had requested him to write Ottawa and ask for an investigation in the matter of the purchase. Mr. Lebel thought that it might be advisable to see Mr. Sauvreau and Mr. Allen regarding this but after considering the matter, I came to the conclusion that it would be very poor policy to go about explaining my action in a matter in which I considered I was right and in accordance with instructions from my superior officer. In discussing this with Mr. Lebel, I explained the situation and he was apparently satisfied. There was absolutely nothing for which I considered I should place myself on the defensive and I felt that I had no occasion to adopt that attitude.

I have gone into this at some length in an endeavor to make the situation clear and in conclusion, would say that I regret very much any annoyance the purchase of the cows may have caused.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Cullion
Indian Agent.
April 30, 1933.

I would point out that no compensation is paid for any cattle which react to a test conducted under the supervised herd plan, but the Institution will receive whatever proceeds there may be from any carcasses which are passed as fit for human consumption. No charge is made for the services of our inspectors, but everything possible is done to eradicate tuberculosis from the herd and to maintain it free from this disease.
I would particularly point out that the responsible person with whom this Department will deal should sign the agreement forms.

Dear Mr. Morris, (Wherever you may be)

Have been thinking about you all week the weather if anything here has been worse than last week, so we had some luck with the weather anyhow.

I quote from my monthly report as follows:

"A very enjoyable and instructive visit was received from Mr. J.E. Morris from May 19th to May 26th, having an official visit to the Agency, and go over the ground with you is like a refresher course, while we had bad weather which threw some of plans out of gear, I think Mr. Morris saw a very good cross section of the Agency. I thoroughly enjoyed his visit and help and information I received from him, and I can also say this for the rest of the staff. I only hope he may be able to visit this Agency again, and that other officials may also come. I hope I have success with some of his projects he is anxious to start and I think I see some action in the making already".

And I do mean just that Mr. Morris.

EXTRACT FROM MR. MORRIS'S REPORT ON THE DUCK LAKE AGENCY -

BEARDY'S RESERVE

The goats at this school are doing very nicely. They are milked regularly and the milk is used in the school. The Sister in charge of the dairy has successfully made butter from the milk and a sample and instructions are being sent to Ottawa for inspection. Father Latour has distributed ten (10) young female goats to Indians on the Beardy's Reserve. He visits this Reserve regularly and will give the goats constant supervision.

Note: Father Latour requested that, if possible, a pure bred Saanen male be sent to him from Spanish. Mr. Roberts - kindly endeavour to obtain one for the Duck Lake School. Note: The understanding with Father Primeau is that all male goats of the Saanen herd at Spanish will be made available for our service at a cost of $30.00 each, crated f.o.b. Spanish. I have already asked that a Saanen male be sent to the Grouard and Blue Quills Schools. When these shipments are being made another one could be included for Duck Lake.

Dear Mr. Morris:

The remarks in your Duck Lake report regarding male goats for the Duck Lake and Blue Quills schools have been noted, but we are advised there are no male goats available at Spanish this year; in fact, it appears the goats there were not bred this year due to Brother Grubb being short of help and unable to devote sufficient time to the goats. However, we have written Mr. Ruddy at Golden Lake, requesting that none of the male goats there be castrated until it is known definitely whether or not some of these may be required for the above schools or any other locations in the West. Would you drop me a line regarding your views as to whether or not the Golden Lake goats would be satisfactory.

I have also written Inspector Schmidt asking him to make enquiries in British Columbia with a view to obtaining pure bred males for Duck Lake and Blue Quills. I might also state that Mr. Schmidt was instructed some time ago to purchase a male Sannen in British Columbia for Grouard.

Dear Mr. Rosey:

Regarding the sending of male goats to the Grouard, Blue Quill and Duck Lake schools as recommended in my reports I wish to make it clear that I never intended that young goats be sent. I do feel that good animals six months old could be sent without any difficulty. These three schools are very interested in the raising of goats to be distributed to needy T.B. Indians and we will have to encourage the project by helping to obtain breeding stock.

I investigated the possibility of obtaining Saanen male goats at Edmonton, Calgary and at any other place where I thought goats could be obtained. This question was very thoroughly discussed with Inspector Schmidt and all the agents I have visited today and in every case they state that there are no good breeding goats to be had. Mr. Schmidt stated regarding the purchase of goats in British Columbia that there are only a limited number available at a very high price and that in his opinion there has been a great deal of inbreeding already. He was of the opinion that if goats are to make a success of in the Agencies in the West good breeding stock will have to come from Ontario.

I would therefore suggest that Father Primsen be asked to hold a number of good male goats until I return to Ottawa. I will provide him with shipping instructions so that the animals can be shipped, stopping over certain points where the Farm Instructors can feed water and exercise them, so that they will reach their destination without hardship.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) J. E. Morris.

RE: GOATS.

You are authorized to buy sixteen female goats at fourteen dollars each ($14.00) and six male goats at ten dollars ($10.00) each from the Rev. Mr. Jones; payment to be made out of the Welfare Vote. You are also authorized to purchase two female goats and one male goat from Father Rivard at twenty-five dollars for the three animals.

This herd is to be established at Norway House; the milk to be used for tubercular patients and the children of families who are unable to provide milk.

There has been considerable inbreeding in this herd; therefore, you are requested to separate the males at the earliest possible date. Probably you can arrange to pasture them on another island until they are distributed. The male goat purchased from Father Rivard should be used with this herd.

One male goat has already been sent to Island Lake. The others should be disposed of as follows:

One to Father Trudeau to establish a herd at Cross Lake.

Two good billies should be selected -

One to be sent to the Duck Lake Indian Residential School,
Duck Lake, Saskatchewan.

One to the Blue Quill School in Alberta.

It is suggested that you write to Father George Letour, Duck Lake, Saskatchewan, and Father L.C. Letour, St. Paul, Alberta, asking them to provide you with the proper shipping instructions.

This will advise that I have been approached with a request for assistance towards an improvement of a dairy herd at the Blue Quills Indian Residential School. The dairy herd at this school is not an asset in this line as they are more of a beef variety. The Reverend Principal is prepared to sell the milking class in this herd with a view of obtaining ten or twelve head of good milk stock. The proceeds for the sale of this stock will by no means cover the cost of the good milk strain required and the request was therefore being made to assist in covering the balance required.

It is felt that approximately $3000.00 will be required to make the total purchase. Of this, $1,000.00 will be covered from the sale of the present stock and the Reverend Principal is prepared to put up $1,000.00, which leaves a balance of $1,000.00. I advised Father Hollande, principal of the school, that I was not aware of this information but felt if any assistance was granted, that it would have to be covered in estimates.

May I please be advised what action should be taken in this regards. It is my opinion that a better class of dairy cattle would be obtained with the least possible delay and any information or assistance will be greatly appreciated. There is a dairy breeders meeting being held in St. Paul on July 15, 1950 and an answer to this letter by that time would give us fact on which to make further inquiries.

W.K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Caroline Minoose, Pupil No. O, of the Blue Quills Indian Residential School at Saddle Lake, who died at St. Paul's, Alta., (place) on 14 Nov. 1944.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

I have the honor to refer you to a previous correspondence of recent date with the Indian Department, in Boarding schools on the Indian Reserve of Treaty No. 7. By said correspondence it is shown that a shocking partiality has been displayed in regard to the grant of assistance to denominational Bodies for the erection of such schools. The result being that, at the present time, on the three Reserves of that Treaty No. 7 (Blackfoot, Blood & Peigan) where the Roman Catholic Church had regularly established missions for fifteen years, there are four large Boarding schools of the Church of England erected with the assistance of the Indian Department; while the Roman Catholic denomination has not been able, so far, to secure any assistance in the way of establishing a single school of that kind. It is true that, of late, we have managed to start a small Boarding school on the Peigan Reserve, for eight pupils; but the old Peigan house had to be fitted up for the purpose at our own expense. My dear Lord Bishop,

The Indian Agent (Wheatley) informed me today that the R.Cs intend to build a Boarding School, Church & Residence at the South Camp at once. Of course one cannot object to their extending their work and buildings on the Reserve, but I feel we have good reason for objecting to their putting them up within a mile of our Boys' Home. We can also, I think, question their right to a Government grant for a Boarding School. My reasons for saying so are as follows:

1. When our Boys' Home was arranged for, the Government told us that we should be obliged to keep at least two miles away from the R.C. Mission, which we did.

2. The Romans commenced their Mission here the same day that we did, namely in October 1883. That is to say that they did no regular work here prior to that date. For some few years previously they paid visits to the Blackfoot and baptized children. In this work they were assisted by the Interpreter Le Héroux, who refused to register any child on the Census list without a certificate of baptism from the Roman priest.

3. It is now therefore over 15 years since they professed to be in residence here, and they have not until now endeavoured to do anything towards civilizing them and giving them Christian instruction. It was with great difficulty, as I well remember, that they were made to open a Day School even. It was only when they were told that if they did not do so at once, the Church of England would do so, that they finally yielded, and commenced work by putting in a Frenchman to teach English which he could hardly speak himself.

4. The present Boys' Home was erected by us at the urgent request of the South Camp Chiefs. The request was made in public by the Chiefs to the Hon. T. Mayne Daly, and the site was chosen by themselves. The fact was duly reported to the Department by the Agent (Mr Begg) and sanctioned.
5. The present site is in what is known as White Eagle's camp, and the proposed R.C. site is in the same camp, and within less than a mile of our School.

6. The Indians, I understand, do not wish another School there. Every Chief except Iron Shield is against it, I am told.

7. Our present Schools are by no means full, and the Agent says he is unable to obtain more children, though the parents express themselves as fully satisfied with the Homes and the management.

8. The Romanists have by their own showing in the Government Blue book, been unable to obtain children from the Blackfoot Reserve for their High River School since 1893. What better success do they look for on this new venture?

I submit that they have no right to erect a Boarding School nearer than the present Mission house. I also submit that under the above mentioned circumstances they have no right to look for a Government grant.

I am writing this in the hope that your Lordship will take such steps as will secure a proper representation of the facts, and prevent if possible the erection of another Boarding school; but if not, that they will be made to build on the other side of their present Mission house.

Ian, my dear Lord Bishop,

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

P.S. The R.C. propose to haul their lumber as soon as their plans are approved by the Department—which they expect will be at the end of this month.

Sir,

I have the permission of my Bishop to address you direct in reference to his communication with you as to our Boarding School work at the South Camp on this Blackfoot Reserve. The correspondence by my letter to His Lordship on the 2nd January last.

From your last letter to the Bishop it appears that the Department has already pledged itself to a Boarding School for the Roman Catholics on this Reserve. I cannot find however that any such promise was made or implied to them prior to 1897. Possibly it is of a more recent date.

Upon looking carefully into the correspondence I find that Archdeacon Tims made every effort to prevent any conflict between ourselves and the Roman Church, and even suggested that the South Home should be put up nearer to the Agency, or at the Ferry. The Indians themselves chose the present site, and as it was in another village than that in which the Romans had their Day school, we agreed to put it there. Every effort has been made to prevent any interference with the attendance at that school.

I desire to emphasize the statements contained in my letter to the Bishop, which he forwarded to you, and which I think should be of some weight with the Department in determining their action in this matter.
As I understand that the proposed new School is not to be erected in White Eagle's camp but in Running Rabbit's on the site of the present Crowfoot day school, I cannot object to the location—though I still feel very strongly that the Romans have, for the reasons mentioned in my letter of the 2nd January last above referred to, forfeited any claim to public money in support of their project.

I have now to call the attention of the Department and to ask for its assistance in reference to the proposed erection of a Roman Catholic Mission house on a piece of land adjoining my Mission at the North camp. From two circulars issued by the Department I gather that it expects to be informed by any Denomination desirous of opening up their work on these Reserves, and that permission to erect buildings be applied for. I do not know if this has been done in this case, but I am wish to protest against this present proposal, and to ask the Department to take such steps as are in its power to prevent this needless friction.

I sincerely regret having to report this matter, but the present R.C. priest seems more anxious to create disturbance than to work for the general uplifting of these poor people. We have the nucleus of an earnest Christian congregation here, consisting of about 30 adults & several children of over ten years of age. We have also 19 Communicants and others are being prepared. We have a Church congregation of about sixty at this North camp Mission, and about forty at the South camp. So far I do not know that the Romans have any. I am told that even the ex-pupils of the High River School attend the heathen dances and hold
to the old life. It is not unnatural therefore that we should be anxious that the peace and harmony which at present prevails should not be disturbed. I am thankful to be able to report that all our christians are endeavouring to carry out the wishes of the Department in the direction of self support, and in addition to comfortable homes have taken cattle and have farmed good sized fields, besides working out in order to earn money.

I shall be most happy to send you any fuller information that you may desire, meanwhile I beg respectfully to submit what I have written for your careful consideration,

I am, Sir,

Yours obediently,

The interests of the boarding and industrial schools clash and unless a better adjustment can be made with the Church authorities conducting these two classes of schools, one or other will have to go to the wall, and it will be a case of "the survival of the fittest".

None of the industrial schools in the Territories can be economically and successfully managed on the per capita grant with less than 100 pupils and unless that number can be secured, the Department will have to assume the cost of maintenance and management or close the school.

Bishop Legal of St Albert writes under date the 24th ultimo renewing his application for the Department to wipe out the debt incurred by the Roman Catholic authorities in the construction of the Crowfoot Boarding school on the Blackfoot Reserve, amounting to $1216.00 with interest. This disposes of $400.00 of the $1200.00 asked for by the Bishop and the remaining $800 could not now be had out of last year's balance which has lapsed.

Similar applications have been received from the Bishop for this purpose within the past two years which have not been complied with, at first being refused point blank. Mr Oliver M.P. then backed up the Bishop's application, when both he and the Bishop were informed that the Department then had under
under consideration the proposal to pay off the deficit existing in connection with the St Joseph's Industrial school and that therefore it could not entertain their application.

The Department has already contributed $2500.00 towards the buildings of this school, which only cost about $4,500.00 including the $1200.00 now applied for, so that it will be seen that the Department has already paid more than half the total cost of the building.

Honourable Sir,

I beg to respectfully draw your attention upon our situation as it is in the present time. I have found that on July 1st, 1906, this school had already 33 pupils and was paid only for 30. Since then many more children came and, as the grant remained the same, we had to discharge some of the older ones last winter, being not able to keep so many children unpaid for.

However, about the same time, I was confidentially told by the Indian Commissioner that provision was being made for 40 pupils instead of 30, and consequently relying upon that promise I kept on receiving all the children presented by their parents. I must hurry to add that after all I could not do otherwise. But the said increase has not been granted and today we are still paid for 30 only; therefore I made a new application for a grant of 45, - I should have put 50 to be on the same footing as old Sun's school, - and I hope that this time my request will be complied with.

But in the mean time we are running into debt more and more: we have already 42 children and 5 or 6 more are promised for Christmas. The department might object to our harboring children over the number provided for, but I beg to say that to refuse children offered by their parents would be
the ruin of our recruiting; the Indians are not equally ready at all times to put their children in school and we must take every chance of profiting from their casual good will.

Then the department might suggest to transfer some of our pupils to Dunbown industrial school; this indeed would relieve us to some extent and in the same time help that institution, but I regret to say that we should have the agreement of the Indians before doing that transfer and unfortunately all our efforts on that matter did not have any result.

Therefore, Honourable Sir, I dare to apply to yourself in our urgent need; could not the Indian Department give us an extra grant even from now for all our pupils, out of the unspent money, viz.: Old Jim's school is paid for $50 and had only $35 on April 17, 1907; St. Joseph's Industrial School has a grant for $120 and had only $70 on the same date.

I feel confident, honourable sir, you will realize our situation and kindly do all in your power to help us.

Thinking you by anticipation and begging pardon for all the trouble and wishing you a merry Christmas and a happy new year, I have the honour to be, sir, your faithful and devoted servant,

MEMORANDUM

Deputy Superintendent General.

Before dealing with Bishop Legal's application for an increased pupilage grant for the Crowfoot Boarding School on the Blackfoot Reserve, I would like to site a few facts with reference to the Schools.

It was established in the year 1900. The Department contributed $2500.00 toward the building. From the day of its opening to the 31st. of March 1909 $13,111.00 was spent in per capita grant. From a report received a day or two ago, prepared by the School, it is shown that there are 28 boys and 16 girls in residence, a total of 44. 8 discharged pupils are now living; presumably on the Reserve. 8 pupils have died, 7 died in the school and 1, two months after discharge. This is what we have to show for an expenditure of $15,681.00. The outlook for the remaining pupils in attendance is not very bright and there is very little hope that the graduates of the School will attain to maturity and be able to exercise any civilizing influence. Of 39 pupils examined by Dr. Lafferty 22 are affected with tuberculosis of the lungs. In the face of these facts, how could the Department meet
the Bishop's request? The accommodation at the School is inadequate for the number of pupils in residence, and the unhealthy pupils should be discharged. I cannot under the circumstances recommend any increase in pupilage. There is nothing of record in our papers to show that the Indian Commissioner promised 40 pupils, and during Mr. Paget's visit to the School he made no promises of any kind.

Chief Accountant.

FARMERS SHOULD MAKE DEFINITE PROPOSITION

The question of a produce market and a weekly market day in Pincher Creek was brought up before the council a few weeks ago by E. G. Ambrose and the market and town property committee was instructed by Mayor Dobbie to delve into the matter and bring in a report to the council.

This committee, through Alderman Harwood, now reports that a building can be secured at a reasonable rental, but the whole question seems to rest just there because the council apparently has no time to consider it.

It is all very well what we should do next.

Obviously, the communication between the farmers in this district have been neglected. We have eggs, etc., bring a visit from the market people who has figuratively spoken to us. This condition of affairs demands a produce market under the council.

That's about the situation. The council is instructed its market accommodation weekly and then, the council in a concise manner.

While there does not appear to be any immediate action, just as soon as the market is opened, the next move will be suggested.

PRACTICAL DEMONSTRATION OF FORCE OF HABIT

Before the days of the steam engine or the gas engine on the farm, the Canadian agriculturalist had to rely almost entirely upon the horse for power as well as transportation purposes. And the horses used on these primitive machines became so accustomed to their work that they would turn their heads away for hours at a time without requiring even a word from the farmer. Tramping around in a circle became a veritable habit with these animals. Indeed, the story is told of a certain horse whose owner becoming too old for further use, was placed in the paddock and spooked by his remaining days on earth. But so firmly had the force of habit gripped this superannuated animal that he would spend hours tramping around in a circle—just as he had done for years on end. He simply couldn't break away from his old habit.

The above is an illustration of the force of habit which most of us can easily understand. But there is a similar practical demonstration which should be more speedily attended to by men who are sane and at all progressive.

In the early days here in the West, especially after the advent of the railway, it was considered impossible to have any kind of a public demonstration or celebration without cowboys and Indians. In fact there was nothing else much in the country. This condition of affairs continued until rapid settlement and the march of civilization and modernism advanced, so the old order of things was forced into the background until today nobody but a tenderfoot thinks about the Indian or the old time blood-and-thunder cowboy. And still, like the old horse referred to, some towns and communities cannot shake off the force of habit.

PRACTICAL DEMONSTRATION OF FORCE OF HABIT

Before the days of the steam engine or the gas engine on the farms, the Canadian agriculturist had been very almost entirely upon the horse for power as well as transportation purposes. And the horses used on these primitive machines became so accustomed to their work that frequently they would turn a horse-power for hours at a time without requiring even a word from the farmer. Trailing around in a circle became a veritable habit with many of the animals. Indeed, the story is told of a certain "horse" becoming too old for further use, was turned loose in the pasture-field to spend his remaining days in ease. But so firmly had the force of habit gripped this superannuated nag that he would spend hours trampling around in a circle—just as he had done for years on the horse-power. He simply couldn't break away from his habitual routine.

The above is an illustration of the force of habit which most of us can easily understand. But here is a similar practical demonstration which cannot be comprehended by men who are the same and all progressive.

In the early days here in the West, especially after the advent of the railway, it was considered impossible to have any kind of a public demonstration or celebration without cowboys and Indians. In fact there was nothing else much in the country. This condition of affairs persisted until rapid settlement of the broad prairies began. And as the march of civilization and modernism advanced, so the old order of things was forced into the background until today nobody but a tenderfoot thinks about the Indian or the old time blood-and-thunder cowboy. They still like the old horse referred to, some towns and communities cannot shake off the force of habit.

Take Macleod for instance.

Those people seem to have the idea that the Indian is an absolute necessity in all public celebrations. They cannot get away from the primitive. They have a high priced paid commissioner and there are a bunch of tramps as well. Yet with these modern "conveniences," shall we call them, the Indian and his belongings occupy a position of increasing prominence in that town.

First, they wanted an Indian parade, but were partly forced and partly shamed into abandoning that an ignorant idea. Now they have broken out in a new phase—they want to pack the Peigan Indians off, bag and baggage, and squat them down on a portion of the Blood reserve, thus leaving the Peigan reserve available for settlement. That would certainly be a splendid thing—for Macleod. But what about the Peigan Indian? He has prior rights and his claim must be considered first.

In the first place the Peigan reserve contains less land than the 450 Indians therein are actually entitled to under the treaty of 1887. In the second place, taking the provisions of that same treaty as a basis, there is not sufficient room on the Blood reserve for these Peigans. In the third place, it would be an utter impossibility to put two tribes on one reserve. And again, even Indian educationalists who are prominent in the country will agree with us that the best method of dealing with Indians is to keep them in small groups, the smaller the better.

These are points on which the Macleod people can easily satisfy themselves if they care to be honest about it. But the welfare of the Indian seems to be no concern of theirs—never was. Macleod has revelled in the remaining traces of savagery, the humiliation and degradation of the Indians for years past, and it is indeed that they parade them on the streets every time they get the least excuse for doing so. Certain Macleod citizens have also obtained considerable wealth through grazing leases obtained on the nearby reserves for next to nothing—and now they brazenly seek the very land itself.

All this has been going on for years on the square as well. But in all western Canada at the present time Macleod is the only town which persists in clinging to old ideas and fossilized notions about the Indians and nothing in Indian affairs, and particularly their move in that direction is carefully scrutinized by those who believe that even an Indian should be accorded British fair play, and when it comes to a showdown in the matter above referred to Macleod is likely to get a real surprise.

It might be feasible to have that 1887 treaty amended somewhat so that a small portion of the Peigan reserve could be opened for settlement, say 10 or 20 sections along the south side. That, we think, might be feasible if the Indians were willing. But to open up the whole reserve, never, not while there is an Indian left to claim any of it.

"MADE-IN-CANADA" TRAIN VERY ENCOURAGING TO FARMERS

There is a "made-in-Canada" train going up and down western Canada at the present time which is actually attesting a great deal of attention. This train is filled exclusively with goods manufactured in Canada. But while it is being described as a splendid advertisement for the country by the press generally, it really is the biggest hoax that has been perpetrated in this country for some time. The whole scheme is engineered by the Canadian Manufacturers' Association, one of the members of which was sufficiently enough in Toronto the other day to remark that "this train would do much to rid the western farmer of his low tariff or free trade ideas."

It will, eh?

Now while the western farmer has to pay $8.00 more for a binder than the same machine can be purchased in England or Australia for; not while a Canadian-made wagon costs the western farmer $10.00 more than the American farmer has to pay for the same vehicle; not while the Cockshutt people are selling ploughs to Americans cheaper than to Canadians. Not much.

The only good feature about this "Made-in-Canada" train is the fact that it acts as a sort of thermometer and shows the western farmers just about how badly he has the high tariff people buffaloeed. If the Manufacturers' Association was not seriously alarmed over the growing prestige of the western farmers, with their U.F.A., etc., it would never in the world go to the trouble or expense of fitting out such a train.

Yes. Looked at from that standpoint, the "Made-in-Canada" train should greatly cheer and encourage the western farmer.

Keep on organizing.
Sir,

MEMORANDUM:

Honourable Sir James Lougheed,

I beg to send herewith important reports from the Indian Commissioner and Doctor F. A. Corbett, of Regina.

When I was in Regina last summer I had an interview with Doctor Corbett, and it was arranged that he should make these inspections. Doctor Corbett is greatly interested in the welfare of the Indians, and his report justifies the inspection.

I regret extremely that it is possible to draw such a comparison between the Protestant and Roman Catholic schools. The Crowfoot, Ermineskin's and St. Albert schools are all conducted by the Roman Catholic Church, and the Old Sun's and Sarcee are conducted by the Church of England. The comparison does not hold good over the whole field, however, as we have excellent Protestant schools in other parts of the country. The Anglican schools in the diocese of Calgary have always unfortunately been badly managed.

The conditions at the Old Sun's school are disgraceful, and the principal and medical attendant are worthy of serious censure for allowing such health conditions to exist.

As you are personally aware of the general conditions at the Sarcee reserve, this additional information with reference to the school and the Indians there will be of special interest. If this band is to be saved at all we must take vigorous measures and I would propose to turn the school into a hospital and to treat the whole reserve as a hospital area. These Indians have a large reserve and more of it should be turned into cash as soon as possible and used for their benefit, and the funds we have on hand should be fully used.

It would be advantageous if Doctor Corbett could continue his inspections and visit all our reserves and schools, but as he has a large practice in Regina, I do not think we could expect him to spend the necessary time in making inspectorial visits.

To W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

Here we find 30 girls and 40 boys housed in a building that is thoroughly up to date and modern in every particular. Though this school is only seven miles from the Old Sun School the contrast is most marked, and exemplifies what may be accomplished with the same people under different school conditions. Here all the pupils are fully up to a high standard of health and appearance. They are plainly well fed and clothed, clean and wholesome, standing erect and soldierly, strong and vigorous and would compare well with the children of any school. Gross evidence of tuberculosis was almost absent. One child in the 70 showing any scrofulous sore on the neck, and that child in good general condition, one side of the neck having been completely healed and the affected side now healing nicely. Another boy is noticed to be somewhat anaemic but examination of his lungs shows no active disease present. Both these children are young and are late arrivals in the school. There is little doubt that they will become quite well under the ordinary treatment of the school. Here any children below par are specially fed with milk and eggs between meals and sleep out on the roomy balcony on the south side of the building and make speedy recovery.

One older girl has a tubercular gland on one side of the neck, which it would be well to have removed before she goes to take up the duties of a home. During her stay in the school, the good treatment she has received has kept the trouble under control and prevented its spread but only the removal of the gland can insure
her safety once she is removed from the wholesome surroundings of this most excellent school.

The children's eyes are well cared for, and though a few cases of ancient trachoma are found, they are all cured so far as it is possible and are not at present a menace to the children themselves or their fellows.

The teeth are all in good condition and no evidence of enlarged tonsils or adenoids found. Neither are there any suppurating ears or skin diseases present. One boy requires glasses and the sisters have arranged that these shall be supplied.

For the number of inmates in the school at present, the building itself leaves but little to be desired, and in favour of the administration too much praise cannot be given. Every part is kept most scrupulously clean and sanitary. The woodwork and floors are varnished and polished allowing no possible lodgment for dust or dirt.

The dormitories are roomy, well lighted and ventilated and open upon wide balconies to the south which are used for sleeping balconies and would be used much more if they were provided with proper screening.

The cloak rooms are a perfect model of neatness and cleanliness the apparel of each pupil being clean and neatly folded and kept in a separate locker. The Halls, corridors, and classrooms especially the desks in the class rooms are in a state so perfect that it seems difficult to believe they have been in constant use for six years.

There is a pleasing infirmary for the girls and one for the boys and a well filled and spotless pharmacy insures the sick of all necessary aids to recovery.
The outbuildings and grounds are sanitary and attractive and a well kept garden gives wholesome outdoor occupation for many of the children. The whole air of the school breathes care and cleanliness and I doubt if another school could be found in Canada that could equal and I am sure none could surpass this school in its thorough neatness and in preservation of the original state of its equipment.

F. A. Corbett, M.D.
I find that Indians have always used horses as their medium of exchange and even to this day they have not been taught that this is the wrong medium and it has been the cause of unprofitable and unnecessary purchases of horses from white men. The schools must teach the boys that this medium must be dispensed with and supplanted by the dollar and that the value of the dollar as a purchasing agent must be clearly understood.

In regard to the girls, I do not think that they get the training which fits them to run a house after they are discharged. Girls work in the kitchen of the school but it is next to impossible to teach them to cook under the existing system; they do the scullery work and watch some white person do the cooking,—this will never make a cook of an Indian girl. Advancement of the Indian depends a very great deal on the ability of the girl to keep a good house and be a good cook. I, therefore, advocate that facilities for cooking lessons be made in the schools and that this be the first consideration in the education of the girls. Crowfoot staff do what they can but I am satisfied that 75% of the girls in this school, as well as others, are discharged without a practical knowledge of the very thing they should know.

Have asked that more attention be given to this phase of their education.

G.H. Gooderham,

MEMORANDUM:

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

With reference to the attached letters which were handed to The Honourable The Minister by Bishop McNally, of Calgary, I beg to say regarding the request made by the Principal of the Crowfoot Boarding School:

(1) That authorization be granted by the Department to erect a separate building on the Crowfoot School premises for the purpose of educating the Catholic children of the Cluny Parish. In support of his request he states that authority has been granted by the Department in other places and mentions especially that this was done at Dalmas, Sask. (Thunderchild's Boarding School). The Crowfoot Boarding School is located on an Indian Reserve, while the Boarding School at Dalmas is situated off the Reserve on land owned by the Sisters of the Assumption. There is no correspondence to show that they have provided a building for teaching accommodation for the children of the Parish. As the Boarding School at Dalmas is the property of the Church Authority who own the building and site, the circumstances are different from those at Crowfoot where the land and school are the property of the Department and were set aside for Indian School purposes. There is no record of any authority having been granted at any school located on a Reserve to erect a building in which to teach children of the Parish.

(3) Regarding the Principal's request for more land, I beg to say the present site consists of 4 Section 32, Township 21, Range 21, part of the Blackfoot Reserve set aside for school purposes. In March, 1918, Inspector Markle stated that the present site of 160 acres is too limited an area for school and mission purposes. He reported that the adjacent land was all occupied or claimed by individual Indians, and consequently the livestock of the school must be kept and pastured within the 160 acres. The Inspector stated that the north east quarter of the same section on which the school is located could be obtained in exchange for another section from an Indian named Catface. This Indian intended to abandon this quarter section, and the Inspector recommends that 160 acres be given to the school, which he states would be sufficient providing arrangements could be made with the owner for another section in exchange. Nothing further seems to have been done in the matter.

(4) Regarding the building of an implement shed; an item of $750.00 was included in the estimates prepared by the Agent for the erection of an implement shed but this was not allowed as it was, owing to the extensive building programme of the Department for the present year, found unable to provide the necessary funds.
Regarding the erection of a hospital on the Blackfoot Reserve under the charge of the Reverend Sisters, I beg to say that this is a matter which should be referred to the Accountant's Branch for a report.

Referring to the letter from the Principal of St. Joseph's Industrial School regarding the case of Stephen Johnson, I beg to say that there is considerable correspondence on the matter. This boy was formerly pupil of the Red Deer Industrial School, and at the closing of that school in August, 1919, he was sent home. He entered Red Deer in 1915, and his religion was given as Methodist. His parents both died in 1918 with Influenza. His father was a Methodist and his mother a Roman Catholic.

In April, 1920, application was made for his admission to the Ermineskin's Boarding School, but his guardian, John Okeymow, and the Principal of the school were informed that the Department had decided "not to transfer any of the children formerly enrolled at the Red Deer Industrial School to any other institution at present." The Reverend Mr. Woodsworth, former Principal of the Red Deer Industrial School, protested against the admission of any of his former pupils into other schools until he was anxious to have the old buildings and school buildings were completed at Edmonton. This boy's admission to the Ermineskin's School was not approved.

Early in 1921, he was taken to the St. Joseph's Industrial School and Mr. Agent Kirby stated when forwarding his application to this school as follows:

"This application is supposed to be signed by Charles Johnson, a brother of the boy, but on interviewing Charles Johnson he states that he did not sign nor make his mark on any application and also that he is not the boy's guardian. John Okeymow is the legal guardian of the lad, and states that he did not give his consent to the boy being placed in a Roman Catholic School. Stephen was baptized in the Methodist Church. He was taken to St. Joseph's Industrial School by Rev. Father Moulin, Principal of the Ermineskin's Boarding School."

In view of the information before the Department regarding his situation, his admission to Ermineskin's Boarding School was refused as was also the admission to St. Joseph's Industrial School, and the Principals of both these schools were informed accordingly.

Regarding the lack of baths and sanitary arrangements at the Blood (R.C.) Boarding School mentioned by Bishop McNally, I beg to say that the buildings at this point are in very bad condition and it was felt that the cost of putting them in a proper state of repair would be prohibitive. I would point out that a scheme is now under way to purchase a site near Claresholm, Alberta, and to erect a modern school building to accommodate the Roman Catholic Indian children of the Blood and Pelican Reserves. For this reason only a few minor repairs have been authorized at the Blood (R.C.) School pending the erection of this new building and the closing of the present school on the Blood Reserve.

Memorandum— July 19, 1921.

Hon. Sir James Lougheed,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your memorandum of the 15th instant, inclosing a communication addressed to you by Reverend Father Rieu, Principal of the Crowfoot boarding school, located on the Blackfoot reserve. I shall reply to the different matters in the order in which they are presented by the Reverend Father—

1: The Department has never granted authority for the erection of a school on an Indian reserve for the education of white children, which is apparently what is asked for in this instance. The Thunderchild boarding school, to which Father Rieu refers, situated at Delmas, Sask., is not the property of the Government, nor is it on a reserve. The building and lands in connection therewith belong to the Sisters of the Assumption.

2: The Department is contemplating the erection of a hospital on the Blackfoot reserve, to be built from the land funds. The Indians have already voted a certain amount, but a suggestion having been made that this hospital should be for the accommodation of the Indians of the surrounding reserves as well, the Department would like to erect a larger building, and the matter is, therefore, at present in abeyance, pending more mature consideration. As to the management, the proposal has been that it should be undenominational and under the direct control of the Department, represented by the local Agent. This would seem to be necessary, if Indians of all denominations are to take advantage of the facilities to be afforded.

3: Some years ago a recommendation was made by the late Inspector, Mr. Markle, that additional lands should be secured for the use of the Crowfoot school, but no action was taken to carry this recommendation into effect. I would propose to take the matter up now with Commissioner Graham, and, if the School Vote, from which funds would have to be taken, if found necessary to purchase, will bear the expenditure, the Principal's request might be favourably considered.

4: Regarding the implement shed for the boarding school, this is a matter that was under consideration last year. The Department asked the Church authorities to build an implement shed from material in the old
school, which the Agent recommended. This they refused to do, and, as the funds at the disposal of the Department were very limited, no action was taken. This question I would also propose to take up with Commissioner Graham.

With reference to the admission of Stephen Johnson to the St. Joseph's industrial school, I beg to say that this boy was a former pupil of the Red Deer industrial school (Methodist), which was closed in August, 1919, and the pupils sent home, pending the erection of a new boarding school near Edmonton, which has since been undertaken. His father was a Methodist and his mother a Roman Catholic. His parents died in 1918, from influenza, and in 1920 application was made for his admission to Ermineskin's boarding school. A protest was made by the former Principal of the Methodist school, and the boy's admission to the Ermineskin school was not approved, as it is contrary to the regulations of the Department to admit Protestant children to a Roman Catholic school or vice versa. Early this year he was taken to the St. Joseph's school by the Principal of the Ermineskin school, without authority, and our Indian Agent at Hobbema now writes, stating that John Okeymow, who is the legal guardian, says that he did not give consent to his being placed in the Roman Catholic school.

In view of these facts, the Department could not consent to the admission of this boy to a Roman Catholic institution.

Regarding the installation of baths and sanitary arrangements at the Roman Catholic school on the Blood reserve, concerning which His Lordship Bishop McNally spoke to the Minister, this is a very old building, almost beyond all usefulness for the purpose of a boarding school. Just at the present time, we are concluding the purchase of a lot near Claresholm, on which it is proposed to erect a school, to be used jointly for the Catholic children of the Blood and Peigan reserves. It is probable that, if funds are available, we will go ahead with this work next year, and, in view of this, it is not considered advisable to spend very much on the old school building, either by way of repairs or equipment. We will, however, make inquiries, and see if some bath tubs could be installed, which might be used when equipping the new school. We have not the data before us to enable us to decide that here.

I am returning herewith your papers.

(Sd.) J.D. McLean,

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th last.

No. 104-2-1 re disciplinary methods used at the Crowfoot Boarding School and in reply to say that the report you have received on the subject was purely exaggerated. Your letter seems to say it is of common occurrence. It is true some pupils have been chained to benches once to my knowledge since I have been back to the Crowfoot School nearly 3 years now, and the same pupils got a whipping from the Sisters. The Indian Agent did not approve of chaining the pupils and this corrective measure has not been renewed, although it had good results in bringing shame on the truant. I do not consider solitary treatment, corporal punishment on a boy or a girl of 15 and 16 years old, even if it leaves the boy or the girl marked, when this punishment is given by the Sisters. The Indian agent himself has approved of it. But since the Indian Department does not approve of this corrective measure it shall not be used. Our policy is to give proper treatment to our pupils. But corrective measures must be taken in regard to the delinquents, otherwise there shall be no order nor discipline in the school and I would be only too glad if you would suggest the corrective measures to be taken in certain grievous cases in the future.

I see you a long way in regard to the formation of the superintendence but it is not always sufficient, especially when we have to deal with Indians. The allurement around them are too many and too tempting, and they are so weak willed, that they must fear in order to overcome temptation. If the parents could be made to understand, it would render the work easier, but you understand the Indians. I blame some officials of the Indian Department, Inspector and Nurse etc., in regard to the troubles we have had these last 6 months. The Indians do not need to be invited to bring forth some pretended grievance to be reported to Ottawa, they are only too ready with their tricks. We try to complain against any white man with whom they are in touch, and much say they have been treated too cruelly lately. The work we are carrying among the Indians needs the support of the Indian Department and experience is being that should be despised in this regard.

Believe me, honorable sir, Yours sincerely,

I have your letter of the 15th inst., No. 109-x-2 in regard to Miss Ramage's report on the Blackfoot Agency, and may say that I have had a reply from Mr. Gooderham to my letter in which I drew his attention to the treatment of the children at the Crowfoot School. He explains that he went to the school after the receipt of a telephone message informing him that there was trouble there which needed his attention, and took Miss Ramage with him. When there he found three boys chained to the benches in the dining room. He immediately took up the matter with the Principal informing him that such disciplinary measures were not to be resorted to. He also investigated the complaint that one Indian girl was severely marked from the result of a thrashing, and Miss Ramage's inspection of the girl disclosed that "there was a mark on one limb", but the Nurse did not inform the Agent that the child was badly marked. He requested the Principal to give him a written assurance, which was done, that his instructions in regard to the treatment of the children would be carried out. This was all done by the Agent prior to the receipt of my letter, but he states that when my communication was received by him, he again visited the school, and emphasized his own instructions by bringing mine to the attention of the Principal. The Agent, therefore, acted promptly and correctly when the complaint was drawn to his attention.

(Sgd.) "W.M. Graham"

Nov. 1.

Late in the afternoon motored to Crowfoot School with the Indian Agent to settle dispute between the parents of the children who ran away from school, and the Sisters. Chief complaint from the children was the poor food. Did not wait in the sitting-room to have dispute settled, but went straight down to the dining room to note the evening meal. Reverend Sir:

It has been drawn to my attention that rather severe disciplinary methods have been used at the Crowfoot Boarding School.

I wish to state that the Department of Indian Affairs will not countenance such corrective measures as chaining pupils to benches and corporal punishment that leaves a boy or girl marked. Treatment that might be considered pitiless or jail-like in character will not be permitted.

The Indian children are wards of this Department, and we exercise our right to ensure proper treatment whether they are resident in our schools or not. Your earnest attention to this matter is desired.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have to acknowledge yours of the 26th instant, referring to the report that French was being taught in the Crowfoot Boarding School on the Blackfoot reserve.

In reply I beg to state that the Department is grateful for the prompt attention that you and your staff gave to this matter, and that we are pleased to learn that there is no ground for the belief that French has been used at any time as the language of instruction.

I agree with you that there is much improvement desired in the matter of English in connection with our graduates of residential schools. You will remember that I took exception to a teacher in the Qu'Appelle Industrial School and had the matter taken up by the Department upon my reporting here for duty. It will be my aim, as Head of the School Branch, to equip Indian children with correct English as if they had been brought up in Anglo-Saxon communities. Then, and then only, will our wards at the age of maturity be at ease in the general Canadian environment.

I am convinced that it is part of the Department's present policy to engage teachers for our Indian schools, who are properly qualified in every respect. I will not hesitate to bring to your attention any matters in this connection that come before the Department.
