COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK. Nov. 26th, 1921

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I have your letter of the 14th inst., regarding a complaint from Miss Ramage that French is being taught in the Crowfoot Boarding School on the Blackfoot Agency. On receipt of this letter I took this matter up with Agent Gooderham, who informs me that French is not being taught in the school. He says that on one occasion this year, he was informed by an ex-pupil of the school that had been taught French songs which he did not understand, but were sung on a special occasion. This man has been out of school ten years.

Mr. Gooderham visited the school on receipt of my letter, and he asked one of the bigger boys if he knew French or had ever been taught the language, and he said he had not. He also took the matter up with the Sister Superior, and she informed him that the children had joined in a chorus of two lines at Christmas, when an entertainment had been put on in the Church for the French people of the district, but on no other occasion had they been taught anything French. Mr. Gooderham goes on to say that all the members of the staff are French, and that even some of them do not speak English very well, which, in my opinion, is not as it should be, as no doubt these people converse with the Indians, and it gives them a bad accent. There is no doubt that the children who hear this language, and are probably spoken to in French, give the impression to their parents and others that they are being taught French.

On several occasions we have objected to teachers in our schools who cannot speak English properly, and have a decided accent. I cannot impress upon the Depart-

R. T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
ment too strongly the importance of insisting on having English teachers, or French who talk English without an accent, in our various schools. When Indians are taught by teachers who speak imperfect English it shows very readily on the pupils. It is hard enough to get perfect pronunciation when the pupils are taught by English teachers.

The foregoing remarks do not apply only to the Crowfoot but to all schools, and the Department should insist on having teachers who speak without an accent, to teach our Indians.

Yours truly,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.
I find that the boys are not given very good instructions in farming, and stock raising, and wish to suggest that more thorough training along this line be given hereafter.

Bigger boys should be made to do considerable of the farm work, and should have capable instructors to direct them.

Sir:

Re: Bob Poor Eagle, Blackfoot Indian.
Neglecting to send child to school.

I have the honour to state that on August 15th last Mr. Gooderham, Indian Agent, Blackfoot Indian Reserve informed me that Bob Poor Eagle had failed to send his boy, Joseph Poor Eagle, back to the Crewefoot School after the holidays. I therefore had Mr. Gooderham write a letter to Bob Poor Eagle instructing him to send his boy back to school within three days. This letter was dated August 15th 1922. I delivered this letter and explained it to Bob Poor Eagle.

On August 15th the boy had not yet been put in school, but Mr. Gooderham requested me not to prosecute as he did not wish to take extreme measures unless forced.

On Friday September 1st Mr. Gooderham reported to me that although Bob Poor Eagle had been repeatedly spoken to, his boy was still out of school. He requested me to put the boy in school and prosecute.

Therefore on the afternoon of September 1st I proceeded by Indian Agency car to Bob Poor Eagle's, where I took charge of the boy, Joseph Poor Eagle, and placed him in the hands of the Sisters at Crewefoot School. I also instructed Bob Poor Eagle to be at the Indian Agency at 2 P.M. of Tuesday September 5th.

On Tuesday September 5th 1922, I laid an Information before Mr. Gooderham charging Bob Poor Eagle that he, after having received three days notice in writing, did fail to cause his child, to wit Joseph Poor Eagle, to attend school. Contrary to Sec.10 Sub-Sec.3 of the Indian Act.

Bob Poor Eagle appeared before Mr. Gooderham on this same day, Sept. 5th 1922., at 2 P.M. and pleaded guilty.

Mr. Gooderham stated that this Indian had been given every opportunity to put the child in school but he deliberately defied the law. Therefore he would not be given the option of fine. Mr. Gooderham gave Bob Poor Eagle the choice of going to Lethbridge jail for 10 days, or working on the Indian threshing gang with his team and wagon for 10 days at $1.00 per day, instead of the usual wage of $7.00. Bob Poor Eagle agreed to work the 10 days on the threshing gang.

Case concluded.

I have the honour to be

Your obedient servant,

I wish to point out that I found the same condition here as I have found on visiting several other schools and have pointed out repeatedly, that although the work inside of the school is all that can be asked for, the boys are not getting the proper training in the outside activities. The ground allotted to this school is about 200 acres and as 125% is pasture there are only about 75 acres or so left for farming and, as a man is employed by the school as farmer, he does all the farm work himself, the boys very seldom being called upon to do any of this work and outside of some gardening they are not taught any farming whatever. There are also very few head of stock kept by the school, they have seven work horses, nine cows, six of which were milking and four calves, a few hogs and a few chickens. By this you will see that the boys on leaving school have had practically no experience along farming lines or stock raising and are placed upon a reserve where they are supposed to make their living from this source, without any experience.

(Sgd.) M. Christianson,
Inspector.
I would particularly draw attention to the Inspector's remarks relative to the inadequate training in farming given to the boys at these two schools. The Principal of the Old Suns school has had no agricultural experience, and knows very little about the care of stock, while the Inspector's report with regard to the farmer and stockman attached to the school is not very encouraging. The prospects of the boys receiving good grounding in agriculture and stock raising under the tuition of these men are not very bright. As I have pointed out to the Department on numerous occasions, training in agriculture and the care of stock is of greater importance to Indian boys than class room work as it is to these occupations they must look for a livelihood when they return to the reserves. Our experience has been that school graduates, in many cases, are very much less capable as farmers and stockmen than Indians who have not received a school training. This is disconcerting, and unless Indian boys receive an education which they can put to practical use when they return to the reserves the period spent by them at school represents a waste of time and money. I am of the opinion that the remedy for this state of affairs lies in the Department insisting that only men who are practical agriculturists be appointed as principals of our boarding and industrial schools, and trust that this matter will be taken up with the Church authorities as it is too bad that all these schools do not function as they should.

I am disappointed to hear from Mr. Christianson that the teachers at the Old Suns School are not qualified in so far as that they have not received Normal training. The reports of the Provincial School Inspectors on Indian schools have been in the majority of cases unsatisfactory, and these gentlemen have invariably stressed the necessity for employing as teachers in our schools only men and women who have received Normal training. I am sure that this matter is one which will receive earnest consideration from the Department.

(Sgd.) W. M. Graham.

Honourable Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th inst., No. 104-2-1, in regard to the Commissioner Graham on the inadequate training of the Boys in farming, and in reply to say that there is a good deal of exaggeration in this criticism.

It is true, these last years, the boys have done very little work in tilling the land, seeding and cutting the grain for the reason they were too young to be trusted with this kind of work. I did not consider them strong enough to handle a 4 horse team or a plough, a scythe or a binder. They were discharged at the age of 16, just at the time they could begin to learn how to handle horses and machinery. But outside of the above mentioned work they helped the Instructor in the caring of the stock around the Barn as well as other kinds of work in the field viz the hauling of manure, the repairing of fences, the weeding of the grain and vegetables in the summer, the hauling of the coal, hay in the winter. As for gardening, they have been thoroughly trained on this line, and I must say they obtained some good results. The Public School Inspector who visited the Crossfoot Boarding School in December last, has drawn the attention of the Department to the splendid exhibit made by the pupils of this School and the Superintendent of Education wrote to me on March 26th last congratulating the staff of this School on the excellent training given the Pupils and the results achieved by them.

At the present the school had only ¼ section of land to be divided between farming and pastures and the last 3 or 4 years of dry weather have compelled us to reduce our stock considerably. This was no way to be had on the prairie, and the crops were light. This spring Mr. Gooderham, our Indian agent, has provided the School with another ¼ section of land, about ¼ mile from the School; it will be of great help, but on account of the distance it cannot be worked to advantage, so the arrangement is only temporary. In the future, the Boys shall have a better chance in having a training in farming, provided they do not leave the School until they are 18 years old. Now, in order to be able to carry on farming successfully I would suggest that a silo be built adjacent to the Barn, so we may provide the fodder needed for the wintering of the cattle.

Hoping these explanations to be satisfactory, I am, Honourable Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Re Schools: Neither school is giving sufficient attention to the training of boys in farm work and care of stock. More efficient work must be done in this branch of the Indian education. At Crowfoot School the farmer is industrious but not scientific and I found that the boys do little or no milking. Stock is mediocre and not fed to the best advantage. At the Crowfoot Roman Catholic School everything seemed to be in good order. The school, as usual, was spotless from top to bottom, and the children appeared healthy and well-cared for.

The farming operations at the school showed a great improvement since my last visit. The crop, I believe, was light this year owing to the dry weather, but it had all been harvested and threshed, and I found 100 acres of summerfallow in first class shape. Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Crowfoot School which was done yesterday; I wish to point out to the Department that the Staff of this school have had a very difficult proposition to deal with during the past year. As you are aware, a T.B. clinic was conducted by the Keith Sanatorium last September, and about 30 children were placed under observation and 13 cases of active tuberculosis were discovered. To carry out instructions as to treatment has made it very difficult for the school, and the regulations have been followed faithfully and the children have been given three meals and two lunches every day, which has meant a great deal of extra work. Also, it has not been possible to carry out the training in household science for the girls and manual training for the boys, as extensively as heretofore. The Staff have done their level best in meeting the situation.

At the time of my visit there were 80 children on the register. Thirty of these are T.B. suspects and 13 active T.B. cases, the latter being kept in bed most of the time.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,

Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The children all looked very well, and from a layman's point of view, one would not imagine any of them were suffering from T.B.

Clothing - Ample; several changes for both boys and girls.

Food - Good. The children are given 3 meals and 2 lunches daily.

The girls who are able to work help with the housework, cooking, making bread, &c., and receive the usual training given in these institutions, but on account of several of the girls being unable to work on account of the tuberculosis, a great deal of extra work has been thrown on the Sisters.

The boys milk the cows, look after the garden, help on the farm and in a general way help with all the outside work.

The school building was as well kept as possible. Furniture and furnishings are all in good order. The building is beginning to need a great deal of repair work and this will be dealt with in a separate letter.

The machinery is in a fair state of repair. I wish to point out that the laundry is very old and out of date, and they have neither a mangle nor a dryer. With a good engineer there they keep the machinery in good working order.

The barn is in a very good state of repair except that it is badly in need of painting, as the paint is practically washed off the shingles and walls.
Farming Operations:

This spring the school seeded 30 acres of wheat, 135 acres of oats, and put in 5 acres of garden.

They have 54 head of cattle of which 24 are cows, and 16 were being milked at the time of my visit. The children get all the milk they can drink and butter is on the table for every meal, as they churn 3 times a week. They have 300 chickens and a few pigs.

From personal observation I would say the children are well cared for in every way.

They have a good staff at the school; as I stated in my last report there was a new Sister Superior, and she is giving excellent service, and things have greatly improved since she took charge. They also have a good engineer now, as well as a good farmer who has brought about quite a change in the method of farming and the quality of the milch cows, &c. Father Riou has an Assistant in the person of Father G. A. Levasseur. He was ordained a year ago and joined the school staff as Assistant Principal last fall. The Staff consists of 10 Sisters, the Principal, Assistant Principal, Engineer and Farmer, a total of 14.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Dear Mr. Christianson:

You are, no doubt, aware it was the intention to erect an addition to the present building at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School, on the Blackfoot Reserve, to provide accommodation, primarily, for 30 Roman Catholic tubercular Indian children of the reserve. However, owing to definite instructions for a drastic cut in the appropriation for the current fiscal year, it was found impossible to obtain the funds - approximately $50,000.00 - required to erect the addition. Pressure is being made by the Church and School authorities to have this work carried out.

As you will remember, at the time the present building at the Old Sun's Residential School was erected, the Indians of the Band petitioned that the sum of $50,000 be loaned from the Interest Funds at their credit in the Department, and this amount was used towards the cost of the erection of the building. It is possible that the Indians would consent to relinquish, from the Interest Funds at their credit, the sum of $50,000.00, to carry out the extension to the Crowfoot School building. I would request that you take up this matter with the Band in Council, with a view to obtaining a resolution, authorizing the Department to utilize funds to the above amount from their Interest Funds to carry out the work. Mr. Agent Gooderham and yourself should discuss this matter with the Indians and, if possible, obtain their consent. The Department is desirous to proceed with the work at as early a date as possible, but the only way it could be done would be to

Mr. Matherland,

The Blackfoot Trust Account showed, at the beginning of this fiscal year, a capital of $1,475,265.77 and an interest credit of $840,969.14. SCHOOLS:

Crowfoot school was inspected. There are 3 classes with a change of teachers in the senior and primary rooms. The Nursing Sister looks after the T.B.'s only. All bigger boys returned and new pupils are being enrolled. Two girls went to the Lacrosse Home for their final year. All was good order and running smoothly, and the T.B.'s were getting proper attention. At Old Sun's pupils were busy and all new pupils of age 7 admitted. A nursing matron has been added to the staff.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Blackfoot Reserve, Nov. 1936.

I beg to submit the following report for the month of November 1936.

SCHOOLS:

Crowfoot school only was inspected. Classes were good, midday meal fine and the sick pupils well looked after.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Blackfoot Reserve.

I beg to report for the month of December, 1936.

Schools.

All went along smoothly at the schools. Christmas concerts and feasts were given and pupils were allowed to go home for three days between the holidays. The pupils at the Crowfoot School are particularly well trained in singing and orchestra work. Their concert was excellent.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days of residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils are enrolled during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case shall any payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, shall payments be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in quarter all pupils ended on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, shall payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet or the Return, use another sheet, piling it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is obtained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of this Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, may payments be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days mentioned in all cases entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payments be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for whose grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupil in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the rate fixed for the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days of residence of all pupils entering the Return and is determined by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case shall any payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grants is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case shall any payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, posting No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Dear Sir-

We duly received your letter of the 30th ultimo in regard to the Linabestos fireproof Wallboard at present stored at the Crowfoot School, and are sorry to note your attitude in this connection.

As formerly advised you, our factory records show that this material was shipped according to your order in first class condition. We therefore cannot account for the breakages of which you complained, and are much inclined to think that they were due to some defect in the sheathing or lumber to which the Linabestos was applied, or probably in the manner of application; circumstances which we are in no way responsible for. Other shipments of this material made at the same time and in the same way as that sent to the Crowfoot School were found eminently satisfactory. This goes to substantiate our claim that the material was not faulty.

Despite this, however, we have made every possible effort to dispose of this material for you but regret we have been unable to place it, owing to the depressed state of the building trade in the West and on account of there being so little demand for materials of this nature in the rural districts surrounding the school. We think, however, you could advantageously use this fireproof, permanent material to good advantage in the School building, as its return to Lachine is out of the question on account of excessive freight rates and the likelihood of damage if improperly loaded.
We assuredly regret the circumstances very much indeed, but believe on reviewing the matter fully you will appreciate that we cannot accept any responsibility and that we are not to blame in any way for the unfortunate experience.

Yours very truly

Re- Electric Lighting of Crowfoot School.

Sir,

The Reverend Principal is desirous that the fire alarm system be extended to include two more fire-gongs, and that the gongs be connected to the lighting system instead of using dry cell batteries as they have had to do in the past. This could be accomplished by reducing the electric current through a rheostat at the switchboard in the engine room. The electric bells in the building would be similarly operated.

I enclose an estimate from Brotherston Electric Co. of $75.00 covering this work, and I would respectfully ask if it is the Department's wish that this additional outlay be incurred.

I was at the Crowfoot School on the 25th & 26th insts. and carefully checked up the work being performed by Brotherston Co. The wiring of the school was completed, and the pole line to the other buildings was finished, but the wiring was not yet carried into the outbuildings. The generating plant had arrived, and was well mounted on a suitable base in the engine room of the school. The switch board was set up, but an addition to same was being procured from Calgary, on which the controls, fuses, etc., will be mounted that are required for the outbuildings. The storage batteries were also in place. The acetylene plant was being taken out, and the first electric light was being delivered to some of the rooms on the 26th inst. The lighting fixtures had arrived, and are now being hung. I was fully satisfied with the manner in which the contract is being carried out. The local engineer is working with Mr. Brotherston and is being instructed along technical lines in the operation of the plant. On the completion of the contract the work will all be inspected by the official inspector of the Western Canada Fire Underwriters Association, and his certificate procured.

The generating plant has sustained an injury, presumably while in transit, which is shown by a crack across the casting which encloses the outer end of the generator. This casting also serves as a bearing for the generator shaft. Mr. Brotherston suggested that the crack be repaired by oxy-acetylene welding, which he thought would be equal to new, but I objected to this and stated that the Department would insist on a new casting to replace the damaged one.
As the crack does not yet extend all the way across the casting, it is not likely to cause any interruption to the lighting service while the new part is being procured.

The engine room of the School, in which the electric plant is being installed, and which also contains the pumping plant, has a very poor cement floor. Owing to either poor workmanship when the floor was laid, or else to the settlement of the building, the floor now slopes away from the floor drain in the centre, and is lowest along the walls, where water often lies. The surface is also badly cracked in places. The Rev. Principal is desirous that this room be kept in a clean and tidy condition,—particularly since the new lighting plant has been installed there—and has asked that a new surface be laid on the existing floor with grade from all sides to the existing floor drain in the centre. This room measures 15'x 26'. To lay a new floor averaging 3" in thickness, properly graded, and with 1" wearing surface, would cost about $30.00 in labour and materials. I told the Rev. Principal that I would refer his request to the Department, and be guided by your instructions in this matter as well as in the matter of the fire gongs mentioned in the first part of this letter.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Knowing the keen interest you have always shown in the welfare of our school, we cannot but pass unmentioned our appreciation of the latest improvement made: That of the installation of the electric light throughout the main building and the outside ones.

I am forwarding a recent taken picture of our lovely School.

I believe that the only dear lack to the good appearance of the whole is the fence around the grounds. We hope a war future will permit us to bring an improvement in this line as well as the painting of the outside buildings whose attire looks most shabby when compared with the richness and neatness of the main building.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that the stable, implement shed, ice house, hen house, oil house and roof of root house, at the Crowfoot Boarding School, are sadly in need of paint. I believe these buildings have not been painted for ten years, and there is hardly any paint to be seen on them at the present time. It is needless for me to state that the buildings are depreciating rapidly for want of paint. I would be glad to have your authority to spend $500 or $600 to have this work done; it may take a little more, but the utmost economy will be exercised in getting the work done.

I would draw your attention, at the same time, to the fact that this school has recently been remodelled throughout the inside, and brick veneered outside, and the building presents a nice appearance. The roofing, however, is much in need of paint, in fact the shingles are quite bare in places.

If this is unsatisfactory, perhaps the work could be done for $500.00. I have no estimate at the present time; but there is no doubt in my mind the work should be done.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned from the Province of Alberta, where I have been for nearly three weeks. I visited the Blood, Peigan, Sarcee, Blackfoot, Hobbema and Edmonton Agencies, and eight Indian Boarding Schools.

I visited the Crowfoot School, which is under the direction of the Sisters of Providence. I found this Institution in its usual good order. The place was scrupulously clean from attic to basement. The school had recently been given a quarter section of land, on which I am told they are going to carry on farming in a small way. I hope it will be in a small way.

There is a shortage of water, even though we provided a well here last year. This will be reported upon separately.

Might I ask, while we are on the subject of this school, what steps have been taken to remove the linabestos board, which is piled in the warehouse at the school. This is taking up valuable space which cannot be spared.

We have just received your letter of April 26th in connection with the Linabestos which we supplied for the Crowfoot School, and may respectfully make exception to the word "unsatisfactory" if same is intended to apply to the condition and nature of said material. As we informed you before, the Linabestos shipped for this order was strictly in accordance with your request. It was dispatched from our factory at Lachine in first class condition, as all reports go to show. If the material was not suitable for your requirements then the fault is not ours nor should you try to hold us responsible for same, as we shipped exactly according to your order Linabestos fireproof wallboard, the quality of which was unquestionable.

We are very much inclined to think that the inconvenience you have been caused was due to improper application or to the unsuitability for material of this nature of the building to which you applied it. We regret your decision to hand this over to the Department of Justice, as we have assured you from time to time that we were making every effort to dispose of the material for your account in the West. Heretofore we have been unsuccessful, but now the spring building season is just opening up, so that the prospects for early disposal look much brighter than in the past winter months. We would therefore ask you to give us sufficient time to place the material elsewhere, and again assure you we will make every effort to do so without delay.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

The following repairs and additions were included in my 1934-35 Estimates for Crowfoot School and should be done if funds are available:

Repair to stairs - estimated cost $35. The treads are badly worn on stairs going to the basement; some material is on hand from last year.

Repair and lining of two porches leading to the basement from the rear of the building - estimated cost $130. The present porches are dilapidated and not weatherproof; they are necessary and should be repaired before winter.

Two bins for use in kitchen pantry. The Sister Superior has been asking for these bins for two years. No doubt they are necessary. Estimated cost $40.

Two Bread boxes - estimated cost $30. These are wanted for use in the dining room. At present there are none.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that The United and Electric Company of Alberta will have completed their line to supply lighting power to Cluny and Gleichen within the next two weeks, and the principal of the Crowfoot School proposes to put in a transformer at Cluny within the next four weeks if the department will agree to take the power at the rate set forth when the Indians surrendered a right of way.

I have not a copy of the surrender here, and do not know the rates quoted, but there is no doubt in my mind the Department should take advantage of the power which passes right by the door of the school, as it would certainly be economy. I am told that the cost of putting in a transformer at the school will be $100.00. If you will advise me by wire if I may do this I will have the necessary action taken.

When this is done I would recommend that the electric lighting plant which is a new Lister Truston 6 KW plant be taken out of this school and installed in the new St. Paul's school on the Blood Reserve, and the Department will thereby be saved an expenditure of possibly $3000.00. You will see from this that prompt action is necessary.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

INDIAN AGENT, GLEICHEN, ALTA., Dated Sept. 29,
Estimates, Blackfoot Agency, 1925-26.

The Crowfoot School barn is now too small to house
the stock and is also poorly laid out. It is 36' x 60' with
stalls for 8 horses and 10 cows, a feed room on the ground
floor and a good loft above. It is recommended that it be
extended 40' and the loft carried throughout; the extension
to be used for horses only and the existing stable to be
remodelled into a cow barn. I enclose a small rough plan
of suggested changes and an endeavour to economize and
utilize space to advantage has been made. The present barn
was built in 1912 and since then this Institution has
increased its farming pursuits and the stock is being
materially increased.

As mixed farming and care of stock is an
important branch of the School work, the larger barn is a
necessity. No silo is included for the obvious reason that,
to date, ensilage has not been grown in sufficient
quantities to justify the expense.
This work which was supposed to be done during the present fiscal year would be a complement to the magnificent work undertaken by the Department a couple of years ago. A sum of $500.00 would be necessary for such purpose and I hereby request that it be included in the estimates.

Sir:

"I recommend again that the Department replace gas engines for pumping and operating the laundry with electric motors. The gas engines are wearing out and require constant attention and repairs. Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a telegram from the Indian Agent at Gleichen, which reads as follows:

"Two hundred forty-five dollars have been expended in painting roof and cupola of Crowfoot stop painter estimates that two hundred dollars further will cover cost of painting verandahs and other necessary exterior work stop Principal states that Father Guy informed him that five hundred dollars allowed for this work stop will you authorize the further expenditure."

(Sgd.) G.H. Gooderham.

A year ago I took up with the Department the matter of painting the outbuildings at the Crowfoot School and also the roof of the school building. I received a reply from you stating that there was no money available to paint the roof of the school, but that I could spend $600.00 on re-painting the outbuildings, which was done in 1924.

This spring the Department took up with me the matter of painting the roof, which could not be painted in 1924, and informed me that there was $300.00 available to do this work, which must not be exceeded. I passed on these instructions to the Agent and the work was done at a cost of $245.00. I am now in receipt of the above quoted telegram, which indicates that Father Guy has again been interfering and has informed the Secretary.

Principal

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Principal that there is $500.00 available for this work, and he naturally expects it to be spent. I took exception to Father Guy going to the Hobbema school and telling them that there was $5000.00 available for the laundry, when I was sent there to put up the laundry at the least possible cost. It seems to me a most peculiar situation to have a Priest, who is not even employed by the Department, going through the country advising the school authorities as to the amounts of money that are available for work at their schools, and on the other hand, the Department advising me that the work must be done for a certain figure which does not correspond with the amounts mentioned by the Priest. This is a most unsatisfactory way to run a business and such methods would not be applied in any business concern.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, No. 104-2-5, informing me that Agent Gooderham recommends that a hog pen be erected at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School, and in reply would say that I have taken this matter up with Inspector Christianson, who has visited this school quite frequently, in fact once or twice a year, and he is of the opinion that there is no urgent necessity for a hog pen. This is borne out by the fact that it would have been inserted in the agency estimates had it been needed very badly. I will not give my recommendation until I have the Inspector look into this and if it is found necessary, an amount can be placed in next year's estimates.

If the Department have any money to spare under the School Vote, I would once again strongly urge that a residence be built for the Farming Instructor at the Gordon's Indian Residential School. This school is in far more need of additional outbuildings than any other residential school that I know of. The stables are small and inadequate to house a sufficient number of cows and the horse stable is very small. The Farming Instructor was brought from the east on the understanding that he would be given a residence. The man has arrived and he is a good man, and now we will be called upon to tell him that he will not be able to bring his wife to live with him this winter. A married instructor is necessary at this place, and I do hope that the Department will scrape up $2500.00 to meet this request as this school is deserving of some consideration.

Your obedient servant,

REGINA, SASK., Nov. 17th, 1927

Sir:-

After some correspondence with the Principal of the Crowfoot School regarding fire apparatus I thought it advisable to take the matter up direct with the Indian Agent and have him go to the school and make a report, and he now recommends that at least six more lyrene extinguishers be supplied. He also reports that the hose is in poor condition and that the Principal is being asked to test it. The Agent goes on to say that it is thought the hose system which we have is practically useless. Now the Agent must accept some responsibility for allowing this apparatus to reach such a state before taking action to have it put in good order. Of course it is primarily the duty of the Principal to attend to this, but when the Principal does not do it the resident Agent who inspects the school every month surely should be expected to look after it.

Six additional Pyrene machines are asked for, and my opinion is that it would be better to buy Tyr-Eyter apparatus, which machines are more easily handled, especially in a school where the entire staff are women.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

Replying to your letter of the 23rd ultimo on the subject of fire-fighting apparatus for the Crowfoot Indian Residential School I beg to advise that Agent Gooderham now reports the hose and attachments to be in good condition, so that it will not be necessary to purchase additional hose.

The Principal has made a request to be supplied with two ladders, which he proposes to house in the dormitories. The Agent, however, considers that it would be impracticable to keep these ladders in the dormitories and I agree with him. He asks to be supplied with two ladders in any event for general use and also to be used in case of fire. It seems to me that this is an item which the school could well supply themselves. However, if you wish me to have ladders supplied I will do so. I am told that the cost would be $20.00 each, which seems excessive for a plain ladder.

The Principal also asks for an electric gong. Would you agree to having this installed? My opinion is that if he depended on a gong to rouse the children he would be taking chances. If a fire breaks out I think it is the business of the Principal and members of the staff to go to the dormitories, rouse the children and keep them together. There might be some sort of an alarm put in the bedroom of the member of staff who has charge of the building during the night. Personally, I am strongly of the opinion that we should have a night watchman in the place.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that while on the Blackfoot reserve I visited both schools.

At the Crowfoot School everything was in perfect order, the school neat and tidy as usual, and the children looking well. I checked over the fire fighting apparatus and found it in good shape. The six fire extinguishers that had been supplied this winter had been installed in convenient positions, and fire axes hung up etc. In case of fire the children would, of course, have the inside stairs to go down, or an outside stairs at the back of the building. The bigger children sleep in the front dormitories and for them it would simply be a matter of crossing the hall and getting into the back dormitory and from there a door leads on to the stairs which run down to the veranda platform. The only improvement that I could suggest would be a fire escape on each end of the building leading from the front dormitories, but I doubt very much whether this is necessary as, in my opinion, they are pretty well equipped. I am just mentioning this to point out that if these fire escapes were installed, or they had some means of getting down to the ground from the front it would be absolutely safe no matter where the fire occurred. I may say that they have regular fire drill at this school.

I have spoken to the Indian Agent on this matter in order to find some way of exit in case of a fire. REGINA, SASK., September 20th, 1929.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to the request of the church authorities to have the Department note for the Estimates the advisability of arranging for fire escape provision at each end of the Blackfoot R.C. School by the erection of a two storey verandah.

I beg to point out that this school has an attendance of about 70 pupils, divided, perhaps, equally between boys and girls. The school is quite large enough (indeed, there is accommodation for more than are now in attendance) for the number of children in attendance, and I cannot see the necessity of spending money for glassed-in verandahs at each end of the school. In my opinion they are not necessary.

On the Blackfoot Reserve we have two boarding schools and the children at these schools receive all the advantages that we give children at other schools; in fact, more. In addition to this they have the advantage of a hospital which has been carried on at a great expense to the band, and it seems to me that if it is necessary for children to sleep outside, the hospital is the place for them, not the school.

With regard to the fire escapes, the Principal was asked for his opinion on the matter and he advised some sort of a ladder business which would throw out the windows when a fire occurred, and from information I have, even adults would hesitate to go down these ladders. They are not braced. I would, however, recommend that at each end of the building a door be put in and an iron bracket with a pole fire escape.

Dear Sir:

On a recent inspection of the Crowfoot School, the condition of the floors in the dormitories was brought to my attention. I found that the floors in the senior pupil dormitories (boys' & Girls') are in need of repair or replacement. The flooring is soft wood and has worn through at the top & bottom of the beds by the action of the castors. The floors in these dormitories are therefore a mass of cup-shaped holes.

If you were disposed to grant hardwood floors throughout, the condition would be corrected for all time, but this would be too costly. I would recommend that strips of hardwood about one foot wide be laid across each dormitory where the feet of the beds rest. This would require from 150' to 200' hardwood in each room and the total cost of the labour and material should not exceed $150.00 for the two rooms. These floors should then be good for many years as the floors otherwise are in reasonably good condition.

If authority were granted, the material and labour would be secured and the work done in the usual manner and as early as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I beg to apply for your assistance in regard to some improvements to be made on the Crowfoot Residential School.

At the time of your visit to this Institution in September 1927 you noticed that the Sisters supervising the Pupils at night had to sleep in the dormitories, and you made the remark that this was not sanitary, and they should have better alcoves in order to give them more privacy and healthier accommodation.

At the present time some of the staff are using the girls' infirmary as their dormitory having no other place available so you see we have no infirmary for the girls.

You have noticed also that the recreation rooms have to be used as sewing rooms which has many inconveniences, and that especially of being too small for the two purposes.

The Honourable Dr Duncan Scott at his last visit on Aug. 1927 had noticed it also and readily consented to have special sewing rooms built. The approximate cost for same has been put in the Estimates but I regret to say that the work has not yet been done.

In August last, I wrote to Dr. Scott in regard to these improvements and that also of having a fire escape for the dormitories North of the building and I suggested that verandahs be built on the East and West end of the Building and this would allow us all the above mentioned, and that with less expense and without interfering with the aspects of the building. Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your No. 104-2-5 dated the 9th instant, setting out the request made by the Rev. U. Langlois to provide additions to the Crowfoot School at either end of the present building. I have not thought these additions necessary, but as a great deal of pressure is being brought to bear upon the Department, if it feels inclined to grant the request for them, I have no objections to offer. I may point out, however, that when I wrote to the Indian Agent on the subject of the erection of the fire escapes in October last, he pointed out that the amount asked for in the Estimates will not be sufficient to provide the proposed additions. Two thousand dollars was inserted, but the Agent states that the cost will be nearer $4,000.00. He offers no reason why there should be this great discrepancy, and it would be as well to ascertain definitely what the expenditure on the extensions really will entail.

If no definite appropriation has been set aside for these proposed extensions and money could be made available, I think it could be more advantageously expended on the repairs and renewals which I recently recommended should be effected at the Sarcee Combined Hospital and School, for which I have just been advised, no funds are available as the contemplated expenditure was not included in the Estimates.

If the Department decides to take any action this year, either in regard to the proposals for the Crowfoot School or what I consider the more urgent needs of the institution at the Sarcee, I shall be glad if you will inform me.

Yours very truly,

The heating boiler at Crowfoot school is in bad shape. In the first place it must be replaced and a new steel arch installed. SIR:

Herewith Vouchers #301 & 302 which set out the expenditure incident to the repairs of the heating plant at Crowfoot School. The tender submitted by Mr. Michael was the only one received although I tried to get a Calgary firm to do so. The price was reasonable for the work and material, I believe.

It is the extra work in connection with the brick work that I wish to explain to the best of my ability. Artesian water from a tank worked its way into the brickwork and this was located when work had started on the job. Brickwork was found to be in so bad condition that it had to be pulled down. I secured the services of a bricklayer, Mr. Joe Davenport at $1.00 per hour. Mr. Michael contends that I was penny wise and pound foolish as Davenport required more time and more new brick than a man of his choice. The Rev. Principal was very keen to have a good finished job and many trips were made to look over the work.

A lot of brick was purchased as you will note and even the top of the boiler is covered with brick and cement. This was needed as otherwise the escape of heat would have been considerable. The boiler was filled with river water and will be used in future as it was found that water secured from the well was very hard on the boiler tubes. The total of the accounts is in excess of my original estimate. I did my best to keep down the cost but all forces were against that.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector Christianson's report on schools in the Blackfoot Agency.

BROWFOOT R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Dear Mr. Graham:

During my visit to this school, I inspected the two classrooms, the building, equipment, and premises, as well as outbuildings, and I must say that I found everything in A1 condition.

The main building is in an excellent state of repair. The Sisters themselves have done considerable painting inside of the school to make it look brighter and more cheerful. The furniture is all well arranged, and looks almost like new. I was noticing the desks in the senior classroom. The Sister Superior told me that they had been used in the school for 20 years, and there was hardly a scratch on them. This gives you an example of how well things are looked after. The building was clean and tidy throughout, and everything was polished.

The children looked exceptionally well, and were well clad, although they only had on their everyday clothes. I was also pleased to note that the work in the classrooms was good. The two teachers have become members of the staff within the last year. At the present time, the highest grade taught is 7.

There were 71 children in residence at the time of my inspection.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

The Sisters
The Sisters were busy preparing their gardens and grounds in front of the school. As you will remember, the grounds around this school are beautifully laid out and are certainly well kept during the summer. This school is one of the show places in that part of the country.

The outside work was also in good shape. They have 26 head of cattle, 10 of which are cows. They were milking 7 cows at the time of my visit, and getting thirteen gallons of milk per day.

The farm consists of about 350 acres, part of which is pasture. They seeded about 110 acres to crop this spring. Their farming operations are not very extensive, and I think this is a drawback at this institution. The boys do not get the amount of practical farming and stock raising experience that they should. However, to enable them to bring this about, more land would have to be set aside for this institution, and this can only be done by getting some of the Indians to move off their places around the school so that the land may be turned over to the school. I believe this will be brought about in time.

The boys do the milking in the winter, and the girls in the summer time.

The Rev. Father Riou is in charge as Principal, in name only. As far as I know, he takes no active part in the management of the school. The Reverend Mother Superior is the actual head and business manager.

The Principal of the Crowfoot School advised some time ago that several closet tanks were not in working order and I asked Mr. L. Michael to make an inspection of same.
