Dear Sir:

Answering yours of March 31st re fire escapes at the Crowfoot Residential School, it is quite true that these are not the best that might be provided but they would serve in an emergency.

The wooden stairs off the dormitory verandah on the South side would be adequate provided they were not on fire. Any wooden construction is not dependable as a means of escape. The pole escapes at the East & West ends of the school are placed opposite a window of the dormitories on the North side. The bad feature in this case is the window but if it is kept unlocked, the pupils can quickly get on the platform and slide down the pole.

If systematic drill is carried out, and all doors and windows leading to escapes are kept unlocked, I believe the building can be readily evacuated and no pupil seriously hurt. Of course, the iron poles might cause serious burns in extremely cold weather. At this time, when funds are so limited, I would not recommend any expenditure in installing a more elaborate system.

Dear Sir:

The brick wall of the heating boiler at Crowfoot School is giving way on one side. The boiler is leaning towards that side and if the condition is not remedied the boiler will be ruined. Apparently, the cause of the trouble is water from some source not yet located. There is water in the boiler room floor and on investigation, this does not appear to come from the surface as the walls of the room are dry. It does not come from above as this room is even below the basement of this three-storey building. Possibly it comes from unused artesian wells near the building or seeps through the ground from currents which are numerous about this locality.

It will be necessary to find the source of this seepage and then check it if possible. The wall will then have to be rebuilt as the old bricks are crumbling and some method of supporting the leaning boiler must be found. I have secured an experienced bricklayer to inspect it and he advises that about 300 firebrick and about 100 lbs fire clay will be required. At this time it is impossible to estimate the cost of the repairs and to find the source of the water, and I beg to ask for authority to proceed before anything is done. I enclose a small sketch of the boiler etc. and in the meantime I will await your instructions in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Some weeks ago the water front on the cooking stove in the kitchen of the Crowfoot Residential School burst. Immediate repairs were necessary and on the request of the Sister Superior a plumber was rushed to the school. He replaced the water front with an old one which answered the purpose temporarily and rendered an account amounting to $6.25—a very moderate charge since he had to drive 30 miles.

A voucher was forwarded for payment but was returned under cover of letter of the 17th instant File 104-2-5. It was considered that the account should be paid by the School authorities from their per capita receipts, as the work was in the nature of a replacement. I draw this to your attention as it is an unusual ruling. If the Department compels the School authorities to make all repairs or replacements in the institution under their charge, it is submitted that the Agent should be definitely instructed that he is not to authorize any emergency repairs. In the case under consideration, the repair was urgent and no time was lost in getting the work done. If the School authorities had refused to pay the account, the plumber would still be awaiting settlement. However, the Sister Superior, at my request, paid the bill.

The School has its financial troubles these days—the grant has been reduced and the earnings from the farm are very small. The demands for this school have been for absolute necessities. It is realized that funds are limited but it is hoped that the schools will not be forced to make replacements or repairs which are unavoidable and necessary.

Memorandum:

HONORABLE THOMAS C. MURPHY

With reference to my memorandum of the 21st instant, enclosing copy of a letter from the Bishop of Calgary, in connection with providing more accommodation at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School, and your enquiry as to whether these children could not be accommodated at other residential schools in the province, I would say:

This school is located on the Blackfoot reserve, for the benefit of the Catholic Indian children. The nearest Catholic residential schools are located on the Peigan and Blood reserves. There are tribal prejudices between the Indians on these reserves and the parents of the children on the Blackfoot reserve would not consent to having their children sent to schools on either the Peigan or Blood reserves.

A number of years ago, at the request of the Bishop of Calgary (Mt. Rev. J.T. McNally), the Department purchased a farm near Claresholm, Alta., on which it was intended to erect a large residential school for the Catholic children of the Blood, Peigan, and Blackfoot agencies. Owing to tribal prejudices, the plan of erecting the school had to be given up, and we still have the farm on our hands.

It is extremely doubtful if the parents of the children on the Blackfoot reserve would now consent to having any children surplus to the accommodation at the Crowfoot School enter any of our other residential schools. Further, the Catholic residential schools on both the Blood and Peigan reserves are filled to capacity.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

I beg to report that at about 2 o'clock P.M. yesterday the telephone operator at Cluny reported to this office that Crowfoot Residential School was on fire.

I immediately proceeded to the school by car and found that the fire was in the girls' lavatory, which is situated in the basement at the west end of the school. The local fire brigade had the fire well in hand using the school fire fighting apparatus which worked very well.

The fire apparently started in a clothes closet in a corner of the room and spread to the toilet stalls and up between the ceiling which was of metal, and the floor of the classroom above and into the air space between the partition walls and into the hall and laundry. Owing to the prompt action of Mr. L. Cretin, the School engineer, who discovered the fire and the local fire brigade a serious fire was averted. Not much damage was done by the fire, but a quantity of plaster, flooring and V joint was destroyed by the firemen in cutting holes to get at the fire between the ceiling and floors and between walls. Several of the plumbing fixtures were also destroyed. Someone thinking the fire was much worse phoned to Gleichen for the fire brigade who responded by the fire was under control upon their arrival.

I requested Mr. E. Gardner-Smith to make a survey of the damage done and he is of the opinion that it will cost approximately $1000.00 to make the necessary repairs and replacements. The Sister Superior is of the opinion that it will take much more than this estimate.

Will authority be given to make the necessary repairs and replacements, please, in view of the school opening almost immediately.

Your obedient servant,

G.H. Gooderham,

On the morning of the 25th August I received instruction to investigate fire at Crowfoot Crossing, from the Officer Commanding, Calgary Division.

I made enquiries at the Indian Office, and learned that there was a fire at the Crowfoot School, but they had no knowledge of any fire at Crowfoot Crossing.

In the afternoon of the 26th August I proceeded to the Crowfoot School near Cluny. On arrival I saw the Sister Superior, I asked her about the fire they had at the school, and she then told me that on Monday night a fire was started in the lavatory, and that with assistance it was put out but not until it had done about $1000.00 damage to the lavatory, she took me to the lavatory where I saw the inside of the lavatory, and the adjoining laundry was damaged a little, also the lavatory which had been damaged by having to cut away woodwork to get at the Sister Superior, if she had any knowledge who had set the fire, she said she had found out from the girls who had set it, and that she had already had their story, so if they told the same story.

The Sister Superior then brought the girls into me, one at a time. Maggie Sitting Eagle, age 15 years of age was the first brought in, and gave the following statement:

"I was speaking to Rosa Mayfield, on Monday 25th August, I took her to the Cupboard, and I got light to it, and went upstairs to play, I did this because I wanted to help my mother."

Right Reverend Sir:

I have Your Lordship's letter of the 7th instant. With reference to the proposal to erect a building for temporary dormitory accommodation for a number of the girls at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School, I have to say that it is not our general policy to grant permission to erect additions or other buildings in connection with schools which are government property, even if no cost to the Department is involved. However, our local officers will be requested to report as to the need for extra dormitory accommodation at this school.

Regarding the high mortality rate among the Blackfoot Indians, I would say that the Department's concern has been manifested by the measures taken in recent years to improve and extend the medical and health services on the reserve. This situation is not a recent growth. These Indians decreased very rapidly after their settlement on the reserve and have barely maintained their numbers at any time during the past twenty years. During the past three years, they have had to contend with recurrent epidemics of children's diseases, which have taken many lives, not only among the Blackfoot Indians, but among many other Bands in the country. I am in a position to know that the losses among the children have been the subject of the greatest concern to those officers directly responsible

- for their

Right Rev. P. J. Monahan,
Bishop of Calgary,
910 - 7 A Street N. W.,
Calgary, Alta.
for their welfare. I am firmly convinced that no pains have been spared, on the part of the Medical Superintendent and her assistants, to give these people the best possible attention in this regard.

I find nothing unreasonable in your request that one of the nurses at the Blackfoot Hospital should be of your religious faith. I must point out, however, that there is no religious test for appointment in the Civil Service of Canada, and that the Department and the Civil Service Commission are unable to specify in advance the religious faith to which persons to be appointed should belong. There is record of the religious faith of some, though not all, of the departmental nurses, and when a vacancy occurs at the Blackfoot Hospital, the Department will endeavour to give consideration to your request.

While on this subject, I wish to point out that the nursing staff of the Blood Indian Hospital at Cardston is entirely religious. If you are familiar with the history of your Diocese, you will know that great objection was taken to this circumstance when the new hospital was built a few years ago at that place. The Department found this controversy very embarrassing, and I may be allowed to hope that no one will insist on raising the issue again, either at the Blackfoot or Blood Agencies. I think this phase of the matter will bear consideration on your part, when you are dealing with the situation at the Blackfoot.

Yours very truly,

HAROLD W. MCGILL

Ottawa, November 24, 1933.

Sir:

His Lordship the Bishop of Calgary has requested permission to erect a building for temporary dormitory accommodation for a number of the girls, pupils of the Crowfoot Indian Residential School. His Lordship is being informed that it is not the general policy of the Department to grant permission to erect buildings in connection with schools which are government property. However, I should like to have a report from you, setting out your views concerning the necessity for the providing of the extra dormitory accommodation.

The last return received shows that there was an enrolment of 43 girls. Mr. Sutherland, who visited this school at the end of September, last, states that, while the room appeared crowded - the beds being very close together - there are ample facilities for ventilation, as the dormitory has a very high ceiling, and, with the windows open at night, the air could be kept quite fresh.

Would you approve of the church authorities being granted permission for the erection of a temporary building for dormitory accommodation - they to provide the entire cost? You might discuss this matter with Mr. Agent Gooderham and furnish a report.

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE,
CALGARY, ALTA., December 6th, 1933,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No.104-2-5 of the 25th ultimo and in reply wish to state that I have just returned from Blackfoot Agency where I visited the Crowfoot School in company with the Agent. There are two girls' dormitories in this institution and I found 19 beds in each dormitory. Four girls sleep in the infirmary with one of the sisters. The beds in the dormitories, of course, are very close together, but there is lots of air space as the ceiling is 18 feet high, and with several windows in each room there is ample opportunity of getting all the fresh air that is required. The school, with the exception of the boys' dormitories where there are only 27 boys in the two rooms, is quite crowded, but those who are most inconvenienced by the crowded conditions are the Sisters: They have no real dormitories are their beds are in small corners in each dormitory that are partitioned off.

I discussed the matter of erecting a separate building with the Rev. Principal, Father Rioux; also with the Rev. Sister Superior, and tried to show them that in my opinion it would not be in the best interests of the school to put up a separate building: The Father evidently intended to buy some old lumber north of Cluny where he said he could get it at a very low cost. The building would be erected in the back yard and heated by stoves. There were no sanitary arrangements whatever, and outside toilets would have to be erected. In my opinion this building is unnecessary at present and Mr. Gooderham concurred with me in this. The Church authorities have been asking for an addition to the school and no doubt in time to come this will have to be provided to take care of the children of the reserve. In the meantime I see no reason at all why the school cannot carry on with the accommodation they now have. The matter of so many more girls than boys attending the school will, in time, rectify itself.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Your obedient servant,

BUILDINGS AND EQUIPMENT: I checked over the school and outbuildings, equipment, &c.

The school building itself is in very good condition. It is brick veneered outside, and the woodwork, trimming, &c., should be painted as soon as possible. The roof should also be repaired, as I understand it leaks in places and especially around the dome. This should be looked into next summer, as naturally when water comes through the ceiling it also damages the walls within the school. I might say, however, that we are not burdened with too much precipitation there as it hasn't rained since last June. The interior of the school could also stand some paint in places, and the Sisters advised me that if a small amount was supplied next summer they would paint during the holidays.

They also brought to my attention that a refrigerator was something they needed very much as it was very difficult for them to operate during the summer without this equipment. They asked me to bring this to the attention of the Department. A refrigerator plant for this institution would cost about $1000.00.

They also asked me to inform the Department that they had no bread-mixer and had never been supplied with one.

This school is connected up with the Hydro-electric, and the only machinery there is, is the laundry machinery. This is a very antiquated plant, but it still is in working order and the Sisters in charge informed me that it was still fairly satisfactory. I had a talk with the fireman and he seems to be very satisfactory. He has been there three years, looking after the boiler and whatever machinery there is, and he keeps everything in very good order. This was borne out by Mr. Gooderham, our Agent, who was with me at the time.

The outbuildings are in a fair state of repair but all could do with some paint.

February 12th, 1925.

Right Reverend Sir,

With further reference to the subject of my letter to you of January 31st, I would say that Dr. Stanley, M.P., for East Calgary, called to see me yesterday and we discussed the matter at considerable length.

We have recently had reports from our officials in Alberta with regard to the requirements of the Crowfoot school. Your Lordship will understand that for the past three years we have found it next to impossible to maintain our buildings in a proper state of repair with the funds at our disposal, to say nothing of new buildings and additions. The two residential schools that are now under construction, one of them being at Lebret, Saskatchewan, are in the way of replacements and are being financed through the Public Works Construction Act.

According to our official reports from Alberta the Crowfoot school is in need of considerable repairs and renovation, such as repairs to the roof and painting. The need for a refrigerating plant is also indicated. We purpose having Mr. Phillip Phelan, of our Educational Branch, visit British Columbia in May or early June. We shall arrange to have him break his journey at Calgary in order to visit the Crowfoot school and to obtain first-hand information as to the requirements. He will also call upon Your Lordship to discuss the matter.

Any decision in regard to building extensions must be held in abeyance until we know whether or not the scope of the Public Works Construction Act will be extended to take care of further work during the coming building season.

Yours faithfully,

PB CALGARY, ALTA., May 31st, 1935.

Dear Doctor McGill:

Mr. Christianson, Mr. Gooderham and myself visited the Crowfoot School yesterday. You are no doubt aware that every classroom is overcrowded, and that the present fire escapes are totally inadequate.

I feel that it is really necessary to provide an addition that would accommodate approximately 40 children. This should be built on the South side of the building. In erecting this it will be necessary to install a new heating plant as the present one is very old. Some new laundry machinery would also be necessary.

The Principal has rough plans ready. These include placing the addition in two sections on the South side, with a heating plant between them. On our return to Calgary Mr. Christianson and I called on Doctor G. D. Stanley, M. P., and he is very anxious to have the work go ahead this year. I explained to him that we had not the funds available, but he stated that he intended to wire the Prime Minister requesting that funds be provided in the Supplementary Estimates to erect at least a part of the proposed addition. If such funds were made available it would be possible to erect part of it this year on the lines suggested by the Principal.

Mr. Christianson suggests that Mr. Gardner-Smith be engaged to go to the School and prepare a detailed plan of the best way of proceeding. Mr. Gardner-Smith would also give us complete information in connection with the new heating system that would be necessary.

For your personal information I may say that I called on His Lordship, Bishop Monahan on Thursday evening and discussed all matters in connection with the school.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
While he would like to see the work go ahead this year, he understands that it may not be possible to secure funds, and after my conversation with him, I feel I can assure you that if funds are not secured, Bishop Monahan will not raise any objection to the work being delayed until next year. I informed him, of course, that you had told me that if funds were not secured this summer, you would see that the necessary amount was provided in next year's Estimates.

Inspector Christianson is aware of the contents of this letter, and will be only too pleased to carry out any instructions that you care to give him in connection with it.

I am having a very pleasant trip and expect to leave here on Monday for the Blood and Peigan Reserves.

With kind personal regards, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Answering yours of the 13th August re Fire Escapes at the Crowfoot Residential School, I beg to report that this matter was discussed with the Principal and the Sister Superior at the school on the 24th instant.

Neither of these officials deemed it necessary to make any changes to the fire escapes at this time. It was realized, of course, that the pole escapes are not the most suitable to get children out of a building in a hurry; they would be used as a last resort. Fortunately, a very efficient and conscientious night watchman will be on the job this winter and every precaution against fire will be taken.

The writer did make a suggestion and that was to have a fire axe near the window through which the pupils must go to reach the poles. I would go further and recommend that fire axes be hung in the 4 main dormitories to be used either to break the windows or doors leading to the escapes. If these were supplied a senior pupil or the matron could use the axe in an emergency. Needless to say, doors and windows might be locked, even when they should not be, and an axe could effectively and quickly break an opening. Would the Department supply four axes?

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Re St. Joseph's School
Blackfoot Reserve, Cluny, Alta.

This school has been on the Government list for enlargement for some time. It is very much overcrowded, and Father Rioult and the Sisters have repeatedly been asking for the building to be enlarged to accommodate the increased number of pupils who are in residence.

It was understood that this work would be done this summer, and apparently the Blackfoot Indian Reserve has some funds available for this purpose. The area between Cluny and Gleichen was totally hauled out last year, with the result that a large number of people are in distressed circumstances. The extension of this school would mean a great deal to this district and to the Indians if the work were done this year and the year after.

I am sure that if you would take this matter up with the Indian Department, you would be able to very materially help us in this matter.

Ottawa, April 21, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

For the past two or three years, the Department has been endeavouring to secure funds to make necessary alterations at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School, in order to provide adequate accommodation for the number of pupils that could be enrolled at this school. The estimate of the cost of the repairs that we have received was, approximately, $50,000.

I regret that it was not possible to provide this amount in the current year's appropriation, but a much smaller amount might be made available and, for this reason, you are being written with a view to obtaining your opinion of the suggestion offered in this letter.

Inspector Schmidt is being requested to visit your agency in the very near future and, when he does so, you should visit the Crowfoot School and discuss with the Principal the advisability of erecting either of the following buildings:-

(a) A two-roomed building with full basement - This would provide two classrooms and the basement would be intended for vocational training.

G. H. Gooderham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Gleichen, Alta.
(b) A four-roomed building with full basement - This would provide three classrooms, a room for sewing and, in this case also, the basement could be used for vocational training.

Either of the above buildings would have to be erected at a short distance from the present school. The erection of either building would make more room available in the main building for dormitories.

When you have discussed this matter thoroughly, you should advise the Department and, at the same time, you should give an estimate of the cost of both buildings. You should, also, state if, in the event of the Department proceeding with the work, it could be done by day labour, employing Indians under the charge of a competent foreman or whether you consider it would be cheaper to let the work by contract.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT RESERVE FOR MONTH OF APRIL 1937.

SCHOOLS

I made very short visits to the schools this month. Pupils did not have holidays at Easter but got three days when Interest payment was made on the 15th & 16th. All pupils look well. The school farms and gardens are being seeded and work is being done very well. Some handiwork has been started and Coronation Programmes are being prepared. The Principal at Crowfoot School wants more land, a problem to be considered and one which is not easy because Indian farmers are close neighbours and have valuable buildings on the land which the school desires. However, I believe there is a solution.

The Old Sun school is not so situated; unoccupied land near the school and in the flats where irrigation is possible is now capable of intensive production of feed and garden crops for this institution. This year, I expect that Old Sun's will grow all vegetables and feed required. Formerly this was impossible on dry lands.

Dear Sir:

Further to my letter of May 20th last regarding the erection of a building to relieve the overcrowded condition at the Crowfoot Residential School on this Reserve, I am now in a position to report our findings.

Inspector C.P. Schmidt spent a greater part of the 3rd instant with me at the school where alternative plans were considered. At the outset we agreed that a two-roomed building would not answer the purpose. There are 92 pupils on the roll and the Assistant Principal estimates that there may be at least 140 pupils by 1943. Whether or not his computation is actually correct matters but little. We do realize that there is a definite increase from year to year and we must build to take care of the increase over a period of years, if the existing system is likely to continue. There are now three classes and as the number of pupils increases, a fourth class must be started. Therefore the building should have 4 class rooms and should be large enough to accommodate 140 to 150 pupils. That is Inspector Schmidt's definite conviction. Originally, I had rough plans prepared for an entirely separate building but we immediately ran into opposition from the Principal and the Sister Superior. We then surveyed the possibility of connecting with the main building and attached rough plans will indicate what is suggested.

The central heating plant is certainly an advantage and we understand that the boiler is capable of heating not only the basement and class rooms but could also heat a second storey if this was desired at some future time. The Principal wants the addition despite the fact that certain light and possibly ventilation is taken from the present building. The rooms affected are either store rooms or staff rooms and occupied only a few hours each day. He and the Sister want the addition so connected with the main building that pupils may get back & forward in all kinds of weather without added clothing. Another reason for an addition and an important one, is the hope and desire to have a second storey at some future date, to be used as a chapel. The basement of the addition would be used for vocational training and a boys' playroom; there is room for both. In fact, such an addition as is suggested would leave three class rooms and a large playroom on the ground floor for other use which is much needed. You realize, of course that a 60 pupil school is housing 90 odd pupils and increased staff and overcrowding is terrible.
The addition recommended would be 52' x 60' with passages continued from basement to basement and ground floor to classrooms through a glassed in passage way on the existing verandah, and would be frame construction with a ledge left for brick veneer. The foundation and footings would be strong enough to carry a second storey and the roof would be flat tar & gravel.

You will note that a 10' passage runs down the centre of the addition, with the end room walled off beyond the doors to the two south class rooms. In fact, there is a room which would disappear if folding doors were constructed to turn it and the class rooms into one large auditorium. An auditorium is a crying need at this institution and we know no better way to supply an excellent one. The small room at the end of the hall is, by the way, an idea of Inspector Schmidt's. He knows the need of such as a quiet music room for the Sisters.

In arriving at the estimate of cost, I secured the technical advice of a representative of the Crown Lumber Co., L. Michael, Local steamfitter, and the Calgary Manager of the Dunham Heating System; also a local electrician. The heating main from the boiler is estimated large enough to heat a second storey and the general heating system to take care of class rooms where there is extra glass space. We have followed recognized school plans. We have not indicated emergency exits from the addition. We realize these must be supplied but our submission is a rough plan of our ideas.

The estimated cost, if done under contract, is $12,500.00. It cannot be done by day labour employing Indians, nor would I recommend day labour with a white crew. Bitter experience has shown us that this is a very expensive way to construct a building. We haven't a copy of the plan of the main building here but the basement and ground floor must conform to it. As a matter of fact, the basement is high - 8' above ground and 4' below, while the studding is, we believe, 14". This means big airy rooms and basement. We hope the addition is not larger than anticipated; we started with plans of much smaller buildings and had to keep on enlarging until nearly double the size and cost that I originally submitted for the consideration of the Inspector and the Principal. But there was no alternative if the Department is building with any long term vision but to supply something along the line suggested here. I trust with the assistance of Mr Christianson and others who know Crowfoot School, you will be able to get a mental picture of our idea.

Dear Sir,

The Department received your letter of June 4th, with reference to the Crowfoot Indian Residential School.

Very careful consideration has been given to the proposed erection of the building that you suggest and, in this connection, it is noted that your letter mentioned an amount of $12,500 as the cost of the addition. It is presumed that this only provided for an unfinished building. The Department feels, however, that it would be inadvisable to build an addition and leave it in such condition.

The funds at our disposal are so limited that it is not possible to provide the amount that would be necessary to erect a completed addition of the size suggested in your letter. Past experience shows that it costs approximately 25¢ a cubic foot to erect a completed building. Under these circumstances, it is found that funds could be secured for a completed building, 50 feet by 37 feet, with basement and one floor. This would give considerable extra space but would only be slightly more than one-half the size of the building suggested in your letter. However, in view of lack of funds, it is all that we can consider this year.

I would appreciate your immediately discussing our proposal with the Principal and advise me, by wire, if he concurs in the erection of the addition which we suggest. If so, arrangements will be made to proceed with the work.

Yours truly,

REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JULY 1937.

SCHOOLS

All children were on holidays but a few T.B.'s, and some older girls who remained at school till after Calgary Stampede. Gardens at both schools are irrigated and are good. Old Sun school has a good fodder crop under irrigation. At Crowfoot grain crops were poor and are cut for feed; the Principal augmented this by purchasing between 30 and 40 tons of prairie hay and wheat hay from Indians. We allowed this to co-operate, but God Knows, every ton offered is needed and then it will cost $10.00 to $15.00 per ton for extra feed for Indian stock. The well at Old Suns was inspected again by an engineer of our Department. The water level is dropping and an auxiliary well is needed, I believe. The basement of this school is being repaired. The Chief's are prepared to supply nurses at the schools for the year 1937-38 on condition that they have T.B. experience, are recommended by the Medical Branch and follow the instructions of the Medical Superintendent; all of which is reasonable, I think. The time is near at hand when this should become a Departmental and not a Ban obligation.

Dear sir:

I beg to submit to you remarks concerning the proposed extension to the Crowfoot Indian Residential School. Of course these remarks should have been submitted to you before today, but we were not consulted about the plans officially and no blue prints were communicated to us.

The schools have been built for the accommodation of the pupils and staff; the Indian Department has in the past, been very well disposed to give us conveniences as needed, and I am very thankful for this.

On June 3rd, Mr. C.F. Schmidt, Inspector of Indian Affairs, with Mr. Gooderham, our Indian Agent, inspected the School in view of finding the most suitable place for the proposed extension, and after having thrown the school building in order to determine other alterations necessitated by this new addition, he came to the conclusion that the only place for the extension was the south side of the building and this also is the unanimous opinion of all contractors who have come to make their estimates before sending their tenders to Ottawa.

On the west side the main difficulty is the heating problem, not only for the initial cost of carrying a main to such a distance from the boiler; in fact we already have a great problem on hand in trying to heat the west side of the actual building, exposed as it is to all winter winds. On the east side, we run into the pressure tank, the cistern and the pipe running from the flowing well into the cistern. And on both sides the building will take up the play ground space of the children; infact on the west side it would entirely do away with the girls' playground which is already very small.
Also if the actual plans for the addition are kept, only the south side of the building would furnish adequate light for the basement class rooms. The actual ice-house will be torn down in any case as it was never satisfactory and is now useless since a frigidaire has been installed in the building itself.

When your Department first consulted the Indian Agent about plans for the new addition, we were glad that an open basement had been provided for vocational training, and in which a dairy room would have been installed, as the actual room in the building used for such purpose is to be used to enlarge the dining-room. In this open basement a carpenter's shop for the boys and a room for Indian work had been proposed by us and accepted by the Indian Agent. However on the new plans, there is no more possibility of doing such a thing, as two class-rooms are located in the basement.

I submit these remarks to your Department in the hopes that they will be taken into consideration before the contract is definitely given. Thanking you for all the trouble you have taken and the interest you have shown in approving an addition to our School. I remain,

CROWFOOT INDIAN RESERVATION, SASKATCHEWAN

CLUNY - ALBERTA

Principal
Ottawa, November 8, 1937.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of November 4th with reference to the proposed extension to the Crowfoot Indian Residential School.

I note that you would prefer to have the extension on the South side, but our plans have been prepared and it has been decided to place the extension on the East side of the building. If a change were made to the South side at the present time, it would involve very extensive changes in the plans and, as the season is advancing, it is doubtful if we could undertake the work this fall.

The Department is extremely anxious to erect the proposed extension at the present time and I feel that you will find when it is built that it will greatly ameliorate the conditions that have existed owing to overcrowding.

Yours truly,

Sir;-

I beg to draw to your attention at this time to the fire escapes at the Crowfoot Residential School. There are two iron poles set in concrete on the West and East wings of this institution and a wooden stairway at the rear. The iron poles lead to senior dormitories and access to them is through windows. Access to the wooden stairway is by door from junior classes dormitories.

In a fire drill last term, one of the sisters broke a bone in her foot which will give you some idea how dangerous the iron pole escape is. Everybody must climb over a bed onto the window sill and then slide down to the cement base.

During the past summer I saw a simple chute escape on a Municipal Hospital and it appealed to me. The chute which was frame construction covered with thin sheet iron. There was a landing at the top and bottom and access to the top landing was by a door. The door could be equipped with a theatre escape fixture, so that there would be no delay in getting it open. Escapes by the windows should be replaced by doors in any event.

This institution was erected in 1912 of wooden construction and then brick veneered in 1922. It is crowded and good fire escape facilities should be supplied. This is not the first time this has been reported, and I repeat it now when you are considering the erection of an addition—a very good time to fix up the escapes.

Your obedient servant,

H. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

Referring further to your memorandum of December 8th, I quite agree with the suggestion contained in your second paragraph that all funds transferred from the Indian Affairs Branch should be with the approval of Treasury Board. It has been my contention that the practice of issuing cheques from Indian Affairs Branch for deposit in our Branch should be discontinued.

Arrangements will be completed with the Treasury Officer of the Indian Affairs Branch so that no further cheques will be forwarded, but at this time I do not think it would be practical to attempt to set up allotments for those funds that have already been transferred by cheque owing to the number involved.

Dear sir:

I have received your circular re: Fire Prevention and Fire escapes.

Though the matter has been reported many times to the Department in the last few years, I again take the liberty of accepting your invitation to make some remarks.

We have a night watchman, who patrols the house regularly; our fire extinguishers are in order but our system of fire escapes is very precarious. We have a fire escape at each end of the building. These are windows, leading unto platforms outside with an iron pole leading to the ground. This iron pole rests in a base of concrete which is raised a few inches above the level of the ground.

We are unable however to make regular drills. Every time a drill has taken place, someone has been injured. So far in the last few years three members of the staff had to receive treatment in hospital. And last year, the girls' matron broke her heel. Since then, the children are so nervous about drills that the only thing we can do is to practise them to get in line and be prepared to go down.

After last year's accident a report was made by the agent, but the Department reported lack of funds for a suitable system of fire escape. The only thing granted was to change the windows into doors. It is therefore my duty again to report this deficiency in our system of fire escape and hope that something will finally be done about it.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
J. River, Principal

WORKS PROGRAMME AT CROWFOOT SCHOOL

In Old (Main) Building:

1. Girls playroom to be turned to a sewing room & cloak room with a partition 25'x14' and door.

2. Boys' playroom to be changed to kindergarten class room and cloak room. Partition 25x14 and door.

3. Junior class room to be Sisters' dormitory, visitors bedroom and a cloak room. Partitions 28½x14 & 14x20 and two doors.

4. Boys' (basement) lavatory and bath room to be 4 storerooms for vegetable, fruit and trunks etc. One partition 28½x10 and one door. Shelving for fruit 2 walls 24½' each.

5. Move bath toilet and partition from West end to small room adjoining Sisters' (new) dormitory.

6. Move 12 long wall closets to new locations and also build 2 new ones 10x12 and 10x23 in new cloak rooms.

7. Rear verandah (rotten) on first floor must be rebuilt. New flooring 95x9 required. This is much used and important.

§ IN NEW ADDITION:

1. Toilet, bathroom and dairy in basement - new partition 8 x 22 and door; moving from main building 2 baths, 3 toilets 4 wash basins with partitions and setting up. Dairy already equipped with 2 motors, drain boards etc. - a splendid dairy and the Department did not buy any new equipment for it.

2. Principal is installing a drinking fountain on main floor also in Indian waiting room of Main building at no expense to the Department.
The action of the Principal is something new but is refreshing. We have gone over the programme of work and consider every move is either very necessary or a decided improvement over the existing layout. In fact, the new addition is of little value unless these changes are made nor will the overcrowding in the main building be eliminated without them. Needless to say, it is the least costly method and we are satisfied that the Principal and his assistants are quite capable of doing all the work set out on the list.

An early reply is requested as the work should proceed through the holiday period.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Upon receipt of yours of June 7th file 104-2-5 I got in touch with the Acting Principal of the school, Revd. Father Lessard. When it was known that only $337.10 was now available for repairs etc., it was quite evident that all could not be done that should be done unless labour costs were reduced materially. So Father Lessard got busy and worked out a programme of work using cheap labour and I think you will agree that he will do more with this allowance than we've ever done in the past, if the scheme is authorized.

In the first place, he would eliminate all highly-prized mechanical labour by using a handy man whose wages are $40.00 per month. He then went to the Crown Lumber Co. with a bill of material and ascertained the cost of lumber required. Attached hereto is a list of the work already done or to be done and the Lumber Company's quotation on material. You will note that the Crown Lumber Co submits anet price of $466.00 which leaves $174.00 to pay for everything else. The Revd. Father asks for necessary hardware and paint which he estimates at $75.00 and an allowance of $30.00 to assist in paying for the labour. This will bring the cost to slightly more than the allowance for this school but I trust this may be authorized.

The Crown Lumber Co in Gleichen is the only firm in these parts and is on the Patronage List. Hardware should not exceed $50.00 and can be purchased locally from firms on the list; likewise paint. In regard to the labour, would it be possible to allow the Principal $30.00 per month for the months of June, July & August for a mechanic, by submission of a Voucher through this office as is done in the case of the Night Watchman?

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MONTH OF AUGUST 1938.

Schools

The writer visited both residential schools in connection with repairs and improvements. The children, of course, were still on holidays and did not return until the sixth of July. The improvement and repair work to the Crowfoot school was being carried out with local labor and the acting Principal is to be commended on the class of work and the amount that he was able to do with very limited expenditure. This school was in good shape to properly care for all the pupils this year. The crop at this school was excellent and is now being threshed. At the Old Sun School the staff was concentrating on the harvesting which came off irrigated lands. This land has produced abundance of feed and a good garden as well as some threshed grain. Both schools had done well with their exhibits at the Calgary Fair and prize money was here for the pupils on their return this fall. This coming year more stress will be given to handicraft work and the general work will undoubtedly be more pleasing to the Indian pupils.
